{{short description|The identification of present hazards as the first step in a process to assess risk }} {{technical|date=March 2013}} Note: Parts of this article are written from the perspective of aircraft safety analysis techniques and definitions; these may not represent current best practice and the article needs to be updated to represent a more generic description of hazard analysis and discussion of more modern standards and techniques. A '''hazard analysis''' is used as the first step in a process used to assess [[risk]]. The result of a hazard analysis is the identification of different type of hazards. A [[hazard]] is a potential condition and exists or not (probability is 1 or 0). It may in single existence or in combination with other hazards (sometimes called events) and conditions become an actual Functional Failure or Accident (Mishap). The way this exactly happens in one particular sequence is called a scenario. This scenario has a probability (between 1 and 0) of occurrence. Often a system has many potential failure scenarios. It also is assigned a classification, based on the worst case severity of the end condition. Risk is the combination of probability and severity. Preliminary risk levels can be provided in the hazard analysis. The validation, more precise prediction (verification) and acceptance of risk is determined in the [[Risk assessment]] (analysis). The main goal of both is to provide the best selection of means of controlling or eliminating the risk. The term is used in several engineering specialties, including [[avionics]], [[process engineering|chemical process safety]], [[safety engineering]], [[reliability engineering]] and [[food safety]].[http://www.unisdr.org/eng/library/lib-terminology-eng%20home.htm] ==Hazards and risk== A hazard is defined as a "Condition, event, or circumstance that could lead to or contribute to an unplanned or undesirable event." Seldom does a single hazard cause an accident or a functional failure. More often an accident or operational failure occurs as the result of a sequence of causes. A hazard analysis will consider system state, for example operating environment, as well as failures or malfunctions. While in some cases, safety or reliability risk can be eliminated, in most cases a certain degree of risk must be accepted. In order to quantify expected costs before the fact, the potential consequences and the probability of occurrence must be considered. Assessment of risk is made by combining the severity of consequence with the likelihood of occurrence in a matrix. Risks that fall into the "unacceptable" category (e.g., high severity and high probability) must be mitigated by some means to reduce the level of safety risk. IEEE STD-1228-1994 Software Safety Plans prescribes industry best practices for conducting software safety hazard analyses to help ensure safety requirements and attributes are defined and specified for inclusion in software that commands, controls or monitors critical functions. When software is involved in a system, the development and design assurance of that software is often governed by [[DO-178B]]. The severity of consequence identified by the hazard analysis establishes the criticality level of the software. Software criticality levels range from A to E, corresponding to the severity of Catastrophic to No Safety Effect. Higher levels of rigor are required for level A and B software and corresponding functional tasks and work products is the system safety domain are used as objective evidence of meeting safety criteria and requirements. Recently a leading edge commercial standard was promulgated based on decades of proven system safety processes in DoD and NASA. ANSI/GEIA-STD-0010-2009 (Standard Best Practices for System Safety Program Development and Execution) is a demilitarized commercial best practice that uses proven holistic, comprehensive and tailored approaches for hazard prevention, elimination and control. It is centered around the hazard analysis and functional based safety process. ==Severity definitions - Safety Related == {| class=wikitable ! Severity !! Definition |- | Catastrophic | Results in multiple fatalities and/or loss of the system |- | Hazardous | Reduces the capability of the system or the operator ability to cope with adverse conditions to the extent that there would be: * Large reduction in safety margin or functional capability * Crew physical distress/excessive workload such that operators cannot be relied upon to perform required tasks accurately or completely * Serious or fatal injury to small number of occupants of aircraft (except operators) * Fatal injury to ground personnel and/or general public |- | Major | Reduces the capability of the system or the operators to cope with adverse operating conditions to the extent that there would be: * Significant reduction in safety margin or functional capability * Significant increase in operator workload * Conditions impairing operator efficiency or creating significant discomfort * Physical distress to occupants of aircraft (except operator) including injuries * Major occupational illness and/or major environmental damage, and/or major property damage |- |Minor | Does not significantly reduce system safety. Actions required by operators are well within their capabilities. Include: * Slight reduction in safety margin or functional capabilities * Slight increase in workload such as routine flight plan changes * Some physical discomfort to occupants or aircraft (except operators) * Minor occupational illness and/or minor environmental damage, and/or minor property damage |- | No Safety Effect | Has no effect on safety |} ==Likelihood of occurrence== {| class=wikitable ! Likelihood !! Definition |- | Probable | * Qualitative: Anticipated to occur one or more times during the entire system/operational life of an item. * Quantitative: Probability of occurrence per operational hour is greater than 1 \times 10^{-5} |- | Remote | * Qualitative: Unlikely to occur to each item during its total life. May occur several times in the life of an entire system or fleet. * Quantitative: Probability of occurrence per operational hour is less than 1 \times 10^{-5}, but greater than 1 \times 10^{-7} |- | Extremely Remote | * Qualitative: Not anticipated to occur to each item during its total life. May occur a few times in the life of an entire system or fleet. * Quantitative: Probability of occurrence per operational hour is less than 1 \times 10^{-7} but greater than 1 \times 10^{-9} |- | Extremely Improbable | * Qualitative: So unlikely that it is not anticipated to occur during the entire operational life of an entire system or fleet. * Quantitative: Probability of occurrence per operational hour is less than 1 \times 10^{-9} |} ==See also== *[[ISO 14971|Medical Device Risk Management - ISO 14971]] *[[Failure mode and effects analysis]] *[[Fault tree analysis]] *[[Hazard and operability study|HAZOP]] *[[HazPoC|Hazard Potential Case]] *[[Structured What If Technique|SWIFT]] *[[Safety engineering]] *[[Reliability engineering]] *[[Occupational safety and health]] *[[DO-178B|RTCA DO-178B]] (Software Considerations in Airborne Systems and Equipment Certification) *[[DO-178C|RTCA DO-178C]] *[[DO-254|RTCA DO-254]] (similar to DO-178B, but for hardware) *[[ARP4761|SAE ARP4761]] (System safety assessment process) *[[ARP4754|SAE ARP4754]] (System development process) *[[MIL-STD-882]] (Standard practice for system safety) *[[ANSI/GEIA-STD-0010-2009]] (Standard Best Practices for System Safety Program Development and Execution) *[[IEEE STD 1228-1994 Software Safety Plans]] *[[IEEE STD 1584-2002 IEEE Guide for Performing Arc Flash Hazard Calculations]] ==Further reading== *{{cite book | author=Center for Chemical Process Safety | title=Guidelines for Hazard Evaluation Procedures, with Worked Examples | edition=2nd | publisher=Wiley-American Institute Of Chemical Engineers | year=1992 | isbn=0-8169-0491-X }} *{{cite book | author=Bahr, Nicholas J. | title=System Safety Engineering and Risk Assessment: A Practical Approach (Chemical Engineering) | edition=1st | publisher=Taylor & Francis Group | year=1997 | isbn=1-56032-416-3 }} *{{cite book|author=[[Kletz, Trevor]]|title=Hazop and Hazan|edition=4th|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=1999|isbn=0-85295-421-2}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20060407092050/http://ecfr.gpoaccess.gov/cgi/t/text/text-idx?c=ecfr&tpl=%2Findex.tpl CFR, Title 29-Labor, Part 1910--Occupational Safety and Health Standards, § 1910.119]
U.S. OSHA regulations regarding "Process safety management of highly hazardous chemicals" (especially Appendix C). * [http://www.faa.gov/documentLibrary/media/Order/8040.4A%20.pdf FAA Order 8040.4] establishes FAA safety risk management policy. * The FAA publishes a [http://www.faa.gov/regulations_policies/handbooks_manuals/aviation/risk_management/ss_handbook/ System Safety Handbook] that provides a good overview of the system safety process used by the agency. * [http://standards.ieee.org/findstds/standard/1584-2002.html IEEE 1584-2002 Standard] which provides guidelines for doing arc flash hazard assessment. {{Occupational safety and health}} [[Category:Avionics]] [[Category:Process safety]] [[Category:Electrical engineering]] [[Category:Hazard analysis| ]] [[Category:Safety engineering]] [[Category:Software quality]] [[Category:Occupational safety and health]] [[Category:Reliability engineering]]

[[File:HAV prevalence 2005.png|thumb|300px|[[Hepatitis A]] prevalence worldwide, 2005.]] '''Health geography''' is the application of geographical information, perspectives, and methods to the study of [[health]], [[disease]], and [[health care]].
== Overview ==
The study of health geography has been influenced by repositioning medical geography within the field of [[social geography]] due to a shift towards a social model in health care, rather than a medical model<ref>Simandan, D., 2018. Rethinking the health consequences of social class and social mobility. Social Science & Medicine. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.socscimed.2017.11.037 </ref>. This advocates for the redefinition of health and health care away from prevention and treatment of illness only to one of promoting well-being in general. Under this model, some previous illnesses (e.g., mental ill health) are recognized as behavior disturbances only, and other types of medicine (e.g., complementary or [[alternative medicine]] and [[traditional medicine]]) are studied by the [[medicine]] researchers, sometimes with the aid of health geographers without [[medical education]]. This shift changes the definition of care, no longer limiting it to spaces such as hospitals or doctor's offices. Also, the social model gives priority to the intimate encounters performed at non-traditional spaces of medicine and healthcare as well as to the individuals as [[health consumerism|health consumers]].<ref name= "Philo2">Philo, Chris (2009). "Health and Health Care". In Gregory, Derek; Johnston, Ron; Pratt, Geraldine et. al ''The Dictionary of Human Geography (Fifth Edition)''. Oxford:Blackwell. pp.325-326</ref>
This alternative methodological approach means that medical geography is broadened to incorporate philosophies such as [[Political Economy#Current approaches|Marxian political economy]], [[structuralism]], [[interactionism|social interactionism]], [[humanism]], [[feminism]] and [[queer theory]].<ref name= "Philo">Philo, Chris (2009). "Medical Geography". In Gregory, Derek; Johnston, Ron; Pratt, Geraldine et. al ''The Dictionary of Human Geography (Fifth Edition)''. Oxford:Blackwell. pp.451-453</ref>
== History == The relationship between space and health dates back to [[Hippocrates]], who stated that "airs, waters, places" all played significant roles impacting human health and history.<ref name= "Philo" /> A classic piece of research in health geography was done in 1854 as [[Broad Street cholera outbreak|a cholera outbreak]] gripped a neighborhood in [[London]]. Death tolls rang around the clock and the people feared that they were being infected by vapors coming from the ground. [[John Snow (physician)|John Snow]] predicted that if he could locate the source of the disease, it could be contained. He drew maps demonstrating the homes of people who had died of cholera and the locations of water pumps. He found that one pump, the public pump on Broad Street, was central to most of the victims. He concluded that infected water from the pump was the culprit. He instructed the authorities to remove the handle to the pump, making it unusable. As a result, the number of new cholera cases decreased.
==Areas of study== Health geography is considered to be divided into two distinct elements. The first of which is focused on geographies of disease and ill health, involving [[descriptive research]] quantifying disease frequencies and distributions, and [[Analytic and enumerative statistical studies|analytic research]] concerned with finding what characteristics make an individual or [[population]] susceptible to disease. This requires an understanding of [[epidemiology]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ocaña-Riola |first=Ricardo |year=2010 |title=Common errors in disease mapping |journal=Geospatial Health |volume=4 |issue=2 |pages=139–54 |pmid=20503184 |url=http://www.geospatialhealth.unina.it/fulltext.php?f=pdf&ida=90 |doi=10.4081/gh.2010.196}}</ref> The second component of health geography is the geography of health care, primarily facility location, accessibility, and utilization. This requires the use of [[spatial analysis]] and often borrows from [[behavioral economics]].<ref>{{cite journal |doi=10.1016/1353-8292(95)00002-4 | title=Coming out: exposing social theory in medical geography | journal=Health | date=1995 | volume=1 | issue=1 | pages=5–14 | first=Andréa | last=Litva}}</ref>
=== Geographies of disease and ill health === Hsenting health risks, from [[natural disaster]]s, to interpersonal [[violence]], [[stress (biology)|stress]], and other potential dangers.<ref name="Philo2" />
=== Geography of health care provision === [[File:Coverage by Type of Health Insurance- 2008 and 2009p25.pdf|thumb]] Although healthcare is a public good, it is not equally available to all [[individuals]]. Demand for public services is continuously increasing. People need advance knowledge and the latest prediction technology, that health geography offers. The latest example of such technology is Telemedicine. Many people in the United States are not able to access proper healthcare because of inequality in health insurance and the means to afford medical care.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2016/02/money-quality-health-care-longer-life/|title=The costs of inequality: Money = quality health care = longer life|newspaper=Harvard Gazette|access-date=2017-02-19|language=en}}</ref>
Mobility and Disease Tracking
With the advent of mobile technology and its spread, it is now possible to track [[individual mobility]]. By correlating the movement of individuals through tracking the devices using access towers or other tracking systems, it is now possible to determine and even control disease spread. While [[privacy law]]s question the legality of tracking individuals, the commercial mobile service providers are using covert techniques or obtaining government waivers to allow permission to track people .
== Health geographers == Notable health geographers include:
* [[ Kelvyn Jones]] * [[Sarah Curtis (geographer)|Sarah Curtis]] * [[William C. Gorgas]] * [[John Snow (physician)|John Snow]]
== See also == * [[Cluster (epidemiology)]] * [[Social model of disability]] * [[Spatial epidemiology]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://sasi.group.shef.ac.uk/ Social and Spatial Inequalities] * [http://www.geohealth.canterbury.ac.nz/ ''GeoHealth Laboratory'']

{{Update|inaccurate=yes|date=April 2018}} '''The Healthy Development Measurement Tool (HDMT)''', developed by the [[San Francisco Department of Public Health]], provides an approach for evaluating [[land-use planning]] and urban development with regards to the achievement of human health needs. The HDMT provides a set of baseline data on [[community health]] metrics for [[San Francisco]] and development targets to assess the extent to which urban development projects and plans can improve community health. The HDMT also provides a range of policy and design strategies that can advance health conditions and resources via the development process. == Background == In the [[San Francisco Bay Area]], between the mid- and late- 1990’s, the bustling information economy brought multitudes of young people to the Bay Area and [[Silicon Valley]]’s technology-inspired new economy.San Francisco Department of Public Health. [http://dphwww.sfdph.org/phes/ENCHIA.htm "Eastern Neighborhoods Community Health Impact Assessment (ENCHIA)."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071111204228/http://dphwww.sfdph.org/phes/ENCHIA.htm |date=2007-11-11 }} Housing was notoriously difficult to find, with vacancy rates at less than 2%.U.S. Census Bureau. Washington, D.C. [https://www.census.gov/hhes/www/housing/hvs/annual05/ann05t6a.html "Housing Vacancies and Homeownership - Annual 2005: table 6a."] Accessed 2010-10-25. During this period, average rents increased by 30% and the cost to buy increased dramatically. Although the economic recession triggered by the [[dot-com bubble]] brought the city’s vacancy rates to pre-boom levels, the Bay Area continued to encounter pressure for new housing development due to extraordinary levels of unmet demand and its high profitability. This phenomenon occurred elsewhere in California and throughout the country, in both urban and suburban settings. == Land Use and Health == Historically, health inequities were associated with differences in health behaviors and health care access and utilization. Today, however, many believe that these inequities result from differences in access to the social, economic, and environmental resources necessary for health. Increasingly, inter-disciplinary research demonstrates that the root causes of disease and illness, as well as strategies to improve health and well-being are dependent on community design, land use, and transportation.U.S. Green Building Council. Washington, D.C. [http://www.usgbc.org/DisplayPage.aspx?CMSPageID=148#randt "LEED for Neighborhood Development."] Accessed 2010-10-25.National Association of County and City Health Officials. Washington, D.C.[http://www.naccho.org/topics/environmental/landuseplanning/toolbox.cfm "Land Use Planning 101 Resources."] Accessed 2010-10-25. Changes in societal conditions can affect many individuals simultaneously, and have broad and diverse impacts on multiple health outcomes. The value of this tool is that it focuses on broadening the range of social, economic, and environmental resources needed for health on a population level. It does so by recognizing a range of resources needed for optimal health at the societal level and identifying measurable and actionable ways to meet those needs through urban development. It combines quantitative analysis of health indicators with a qualitative assessment of whether plans and projects meet tool development targets. SFDPH has recognized that it has a legitimate agency interest in integrating health considerations into land use decision-making. While SFDPH does not have formal decision-making authority regarding land use and development decisions, a number of drivers brought SFDPH to understand that it has a potentially important role. Drivers include: * Community organizations’ struggles to limit the negative impacts of development in their communities * Local experience among SFDPH staff that environmental health outcomes were associated with land use and transportation decisions * National public health research that “the built environment” was associated with chronic health outcomes * An international movement to develop tools and methods for HIA’s of public policy The first driver for SFDPH to be involved in land use was that community groups were struggling with the pace of development in their neighborhoods. In addition, they were dissatisfied with the responsiveness of the Planning Department to address neighborhood needs and concerns, including displacement of existing residents and jobs, and an overall lack of infrastructure to support a complete neighborhood. Many groups called for community planning processes and specifically community, social, and economic impact assessments of land use changes to be conducted as part of or complementary to the environmental impact report required by CEQA.California Natural Resources Agency. Sacramento, CA. [http://ceres.ca.gov/topic/env_law/ceqa/summary.html "California Environmental Quality Act: Summary."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090129130447/http://ceres.ca.gov/topic/env_law/ceqa/summary.html |date=2009-01-29 }} 2005-05-25. The second driver was that SFDPH increasingly recognized that environmental health and justice issues in San Francisco had roots in land use and transportation planning decisions. For example, SFDPH environmental health inspectors frequently observed that families lived in housing conditions that caused a variety of health outcomes such as asthma and lead poisoning. However, because of the high costs associated with improving these conditions, landlords often would not take action. In addition, the high cost of housing made it difficult or families to leave their homes and find new places to live. Cumulatively, SFDPH also observed the disproportionate share of unwanted land uses (such as power plants, sewage treatment facilities, substandard public housing, and poor public infrastructure) in places like Bayview/[[Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco|Hunters Point]] as contributing to significant disparities in life expectancy for residents. Finally, SFDPH also witnessed residential development in historically industrial areas generating [[noise pollution|noise]], [[air pollution|traffic emissions]], and pedestrian hazards for residents and workers in these areas. Third, on a national scale, the public health and urban planning communities were increasingly calling attention to the connections between the built environment (that is, land use, transportation systems, and community design) and health, particularly focusing on the contribution of the land use patterns (for example, sprawl) to physical inactivity, pedestrian safety, and air quality. Findings illustrated that urban design and land use regulations could accomplish the complementary goals of preventing illness and ensuring environmental quality. For example, creating higher density, mixed-use developments closer to transit and job centers would enhance public safety, prevent motor-vehicle injuries, increase access to goods and services, encourage walking or bicycling, reduce air pollution, and limit global warming. Finally, on an international scale, public health practitioners were also developing methods and tools for [[Health Impact Assessment]]. The goal of HIA was to bring to light information on how diverse public policy decisions might affect health as well as the social and environmental resources required for good health. While HIA was novel in the United States, it presented a potential way to gain consideration more pro-actively of both root causes of poor health and community needs in the land use development process. By 2001, SFDPH had already begun using HIA methods to increase the inclusion of health considerations in policy-making. In a study examining the health impacts of increasing the city’s [[living wage]], SFDPH found that adoption of an increased living wage would result in decreases in the risk of premature death by 5% for adults 24–44 years of age in households whose current income was around $20,000. For the offspring of these workers, a living wage would result in an increase of a quarter of a year of completed education, a 34% increase in the odds of high school completion, and a 22% decrease in the risk of early childbirth. SFDPH also conducted exploratory workshops with community members on the health impacts of housing subsidies, farmers’ markets, and green schoolyards. In 2002, SFDPH began using HIA more specifically in local land use planning, policy making, and project review. For example, SFDPH conducted HIAs of: * Carpet policy in public housing; * Housing displacement at Trinity Plaza; and * Spear / Folsom condominium towers at Rincon Hill. == ENCHIA Process == In response to development pressures, many communities called on public health officials to evaluate the ensuing health impacts and to advocate for healthy environments. For this reason, the San Francisco Department of Public Health initiated the Eastern Neighborhoods Community Health Impact Assessment (ENCHIA) to analyze how development affects [[social determinants of health]] within several San Francisco neighborhoods. The HDMT was created through collaboration among development stakeholders and public agencies in [[San Francisco]] as a result of the ENCHIA. The process was guided by the principles of "health impact assessment" and designed to act on growing scientific understanding that optimal health cannot be achieved by improving health services or individual behavior change alone, but requires advancing healthful neighborhood conditions. Such conditions include: * Adequate housing * Access to public transit * Schools, parks and public spaces * Safe routes for pedestrians and bicyclists * Meaningful and productive employment * Unpolluted air, soil, and water * Cooperation, trust, and civic participation Facilitated and staffed by SFDPH, the eighteen-month ENCHIA process was guided by a multi-stakeholder Community Council of over twenty diverse organizations including: * Community planning and design * Economic and neighborhood development * Environmental justice * Homeless * Open space * Housing * Transportation * Bicycle * Food systems * Child care and childhood development advocates * Low-wage and union workers * Non-profit and private developers * Property-owners * Architects * Small businesses == Components == ;Voluntary, not regulatory approach This tool is not a new form of environmental regulation or a set of enforceable standards. The tool does not mandate the achievement of specific development targets. Similar to tools such as [[Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design]] (LEED), this tool is intended to encourage voluntary efforts to improve health-oriented development. HDMT provides a systematic assessment approach to simultaneously consider effects of development on six overarching domains: * Environmental stewardship * Sustainable and safe transportation * Social cohesion * Adequate and healthy housing * Public infrastructure/access to goods and services * Healthy economy These six elements are divided into 27 objectives, which themselves are further divided into 107 measurable indicators. Most indicators are paired with specific, actionable development targets, usually as a benchmark and/or minimum. As of November 1, 2007, fourteen of these indicators are in process. The San Francisco Planning Department has received and reviewed the HDMT and other ENCHIA products and has committed to using the indicators and development criteria, where possible, in screening the content of its Eastern Neighborhood plans. This tool comprises a set of metrics to evaluate the extent to which urban development is meeting the needs of human health. Measurable indicators and development targets provide information about both the positive and negative ways in which health is impacted by a proposed development project and focuses attention on ways that development can improve population health. By providing measures and criteria for development, it allows those involved in policy- and decision-making to make more informed choices between trade-offs. As a result, the tool may provide an additional means to support greater transparency in development processes. == Flowchart == This diagram depicts the relationship of many of the tool's components.
[[File:Healthy development measurement tool (diagram).png]] == Examples of Application == Thus far, SFDPH has applied the HDMT to evaluate San Francisco's Eastern neighborhoods. Pilot applications for smaller geographical areas are ongoing. == See also == *[[Built Environment]] *[[Health Impact Assessment]] *[[Environmental Health]] *[[Leopold matrix]] (environmental impact assessment method) *[[Pedestrian-friendly]] *[[Traffic calming]] *[[Affordable housing]] *[[Gentrification]] *[[Geographic information system]] == References == {{Reflist}} {{Refbegin}} {{cite journal | author1 = Farhang, Lili | author2 = Bhatia, Rajiv | title = Eastern Neighborhoods Community Health Impact Assessment | version = Final Report | publisher = San Francisco Department of Public Health | year = 2007 | url = http://dphwww.sfdph.org/phes/ENCHIA.htm | accessdate = 2007-11-02 | journal = — | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071111204228/http://dphwww.sfdph.org/phes/ENCHIA.htm | archive-date = 2007-11-11 | dead-url = yes | df = }} {{Refend}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071117162246/http://www.thehdmt.org/ Healthy Development Measurement Tool] *[https://www.sfdph.org/dph/EH/PHES/PHES/default.asp Program on Health, Equity and Sustainability] - San Francisco Department of Public Health *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060905205604/http://ehs.sph.berkeley.edu/hia/Default.htm UC Berkeley Health Impact Group] [[Category:Public health]] [[Category:Environmental health]] [[Category:Health care]]

{{Use British English|date=October 2016}} '''High-altitude adaptation in humans''' is an instance of [[evolutionary adaptation|evolutionary modification]] in certain human populations, including those of [[Tibetan people|Tibet]] in Asia, the [[Andes]] of the Americas, and [[People of Ethiopia|Ethiopia]] in Africa, who have acquired the ability to survive at extremely high [[altitudes]]. This adaptation means irreversible, [[adaptive evolution|long-term physiological responses]] to high-altitude environments, associated with heritable [[ethology|behavioural]] and [[mutation|genetic changes]].
While the rest of the human population would suffer serious health consequences, the indigenous inhabitants of these regions thrive well in the highest parts of the world. These people have undergone extensive physiological and genetic changes, particularly in the regulatory systems of oxygen [[respiratory system|respiration]] and blood [[circulatory system|circulation]], when compared to the general lowland population.<ref name=fris>{{cite book|author=Frisancho AR|title=Human Adaptation and Accommodation|year=1993|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-K_SYHBo42MC&pg|pages=175–301 |isbn =0472095110|publisher=University of Michigan Press}}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author=Hillary Mayell |title=Three High-Altitude Peoples, Three Adaptations to Thin Air|date=24 February 2004 | url=http://news.nationalgeographic.co.in/news/2004/02/0224_040225_evolution.html |work=National Geographic News |publisher=National Geographic Society |accessdate=1 September 2013}}</ref>
This special [[adaptation]] is now recognised as an example of [[natural selection]] in action.<ref name=bigh>{{cite journal|author=Bigham A, Bauchet M, Pinto D, Mao X, Akey JM, Mei R, Scherer SW, Julian CG, Wilson MJ, López Herráez D, Brutsaert T, Parra EJ, Moore LG, Shriver MD |year=2010 |title=Identifying signatures of natural selection in Tibetan and Andean populations using dense genome scan data | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1001116 |journal=PLOS Genetics |volume=6 |issue=9|pages=e1001116|pmid=20838600 |pmc=2936536 |doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1001116|last2=Bauchet |last3=Pinto |last4=Mao |last5=Akey |last6=Mei |last7=Scherer |last8=Julian |last9=Wilson |last10=López Herráez |last11=Brutsaert |last12=Parra |last13=Moore |last14=Shriver }}</ref> The adaptation account of the Tibetans has become the fastest case of [[human evolution]] in the scientific record, as it is estimated to have occurred in less than 3,000 years.<ref>{{cite web|author =Sanders R |title=Tibetans adapted to high altitude in less than 3,000 years|url=http://newscenter.berkeley.edu/2010/07/01/tibetan_genome/ | date=1 July 2010 |work=News Centre, UC Berkeley |publisher=UC Regents|accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author =Hsu J |title=Tibetans Underwent Fastest Evolution Seen in Humans |url=http://www.livescience.com/6663-tibetans-underwent-fastest-evolution-humans.html | date=1 July 2010| work=Live Science | publisher=TechMediaNetwork.com| accessdate=2013-07-08}}</ref><ref name=yi>{{cite journal |last1=Yi |first1=X. |last2=Liang|first2=Y. |last3=Huerta-Sanchez |first3=E. |last4=Jin |first4=X. |last5=Cuo |first5=Z. X. P. |last6=Pool |first6=J. E. |last7=Xu |first7=X. |last8=Jiang |first8=H. |last9=Vinckenbosch |first9=N. |last10=Korneliussen |first10=T. S. |last11=Zheng |first11=H. |last12=Liu |first12=T. |last13=He |first13=W. |last14=Li |first14=K. |last15=Luo |first15=R. |last16=Nie |first16=X. |last17=Wu |first17=H. |last18=Zhao |first18=M. |last19=Cao |first19=H. |last20=Zou |first20=J. |last21=Shan |first21=Y. |last22=Li |first22=S. |last23=Yang |first23=Q. |last24=Asan |last25=Ni |first25=P. |last26=Tian |first26=G. |last27=Xu |first27=J. |last28=Liu |first28=X. |last29=Jiang |first29=T. |last30=Wu |first30=R. |last31=Zhou |first31=G. |last32=Tang |first32=M. |last33=Qin |first33=J. |last34=Wang |first34=T. |last35=Feng |first35=S. |last36=Li |first36=G. |last37=Huasang |last38=Luosang |first38=J. |last39=Wang |first39=W. |last40=Chen |first40=F. |last41=Wang |first41=Y. |last42=Zheng |first42=X. |last43=Li |first43=Z. |last44=Bianba |first44=Z. |last45=Yang|first45=G. |last46=Wang |first46=X. |last47=Tang|first47=S. |last48=Gao |first48=G. |last49=Chen|first49=Y. |last50=Luo |first50=Z. |last51=Gusang |first51=L. |last52=Cao |first52=Z. |last53=Zhang|first53=Q. |last54=Ouyang |first54=W. |last55=Ren |first55=X. |last56=Liang |first56=H. |last57=Zheng|first57=H. |last58=Huang|first58=Y. |last59=Li |first59=J. |last60=Bolund |first60=L. |last61=Kristiansen |first61=K. |last62=Li |first62=Y. |last63=Zhang |first63=Y. |last64=Zhang |first64=X. |last65=Li |first65=R. |last66=Li |first66=S. |last67=Yang |first67=H. |last68=Nielsen |first68=R. |last69=Wang |first69=J. |last70=Wang|first70=J. |title=Sequencing of 50 human exomes reveals adaptation to high altitude |journal=Science |year=2010 |volume=329 |issue=5987 |pages=75–78 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/329/5987/75 |pmid=20595611 |pmc=3711608 |doi=10.1126/science.1190371 |displayauthors=8 |bibcode=2010Sci...329...75Y}}</ref>
Modern humans [[Recent African origin of modern humans|dispersed from Africa less than 100,000 years ago]], and eventually colonized the rest of the world,<ref>{{cite journal |author=Templeton, A. R. |year=2002|url=http://www.bioguider.com/ebook/biology/pdf/Templeton_n2002.pdf |title=Out of Africa again and again |journal=[[Nature (journal)|Nature]] |volume=416 |pages=45–51 |doi=10.1038/416045a |issue=6876}}</ref> including the harshest environments of extreme [[polar climate|cold]] and [[alpine climate|high mountains]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jeong|first1=Choongwon |last2=Di Rienzo |first2=Anna|title=Adaptations to local environments in modern human populations |journal=Current Opinion in Genetics & Development |year=2014 |volume=29 |pages=1–8 |doi=10.1016/j.gde.2014.06.011 |pmid=25129844 |pmc=4258478}}</ref> The abundance of [[oxygen]] in the [[atmosphere]] is inversely related to [[altitude]] from the [[sea level]]; hence, the highest mountain ranges of the world are considered unsuitable for human habitation.
Nevertheless, around 140 million people, just under 2% of the world's human population, live permanently at high [[altitude]]s, that is, at heights above {{convert|2,500|m|ft}} in [[South America]], [[East Africa]], and [[South Asia]]. These populations have done so for [[millennium|millennia]] without apparent complications.<ref name=moor>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG |year=1983 |title=Human genetic adaptation to high altitude| url=http://anthro.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441?requestedContent=related& |journal=High Altitude Medical Biology |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=257–279 |pmid=11443005 |doi=10.1089/152702901750265341}}</ref> The overwhelming majority, over 98% of humans from other parts of the world, normally suffer symptoms of [[altitude sickness]] in these regions, often resulting in life-threatening [[Major trauma|trauma]] and even death.
Studies on the detail biological mechanism have revealed that adaptation of the Tibetans, Andeans and Ethiopians is indeed an observable instance of the process of natural selection in acting on [[fitness (biology)|favourable characters]] such as enhanced [[respiratory system|respiratory mechanisms]] in humans.<ref name=mue>{{cite book|author =Muehlenbein, MP |year=2010 |title=Human Evolutionary Biology|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=1VXX1jkhPH8C&pg|publisher=Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, UK |pages=170–191 |isbn=0521879485}}</ref><ref name=bea07>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM |year=2007|title=Detecting natural selection in high-altitude human populations | journal=Respir Physiol Neurobiol |volume=158|issue=2–3|pages=161–171 |pmid=17644049 |doi=10.1016/j.resp.2007.05.013 }}</ref>
==Origin and basis== [[File:Himalayas-Lhasa15.JPG|thumb|upright|Himalayas, on the southern rim of the Tibetan Plateau]]
[[Homo sapiens|Humans]] are naturally adapted to [[lowland]] environment where oxygen is abundant.<ref name=moo>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG, Regensteine JG|year=1983 |pmid=|title=Adaptation to High Altitude| url=http://anthro.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441?requestedContent=related& |journal=Annual Review of Anthropology |volume=12 |pages=285–304 |doi=10.1146/annurev.an.12.100183.001441 |last2=Regensteiner }}</ref> When people from the general lowlands go to altitudes above {{convert|2,500|m|ft}}, with atmospheric pressure 74% of normal<ref>[https://www.mide.com/pages/air-pressure-at-altitude-calculator Air pressure at altitude calculator]</ref>{{cn|date=May 2018}} they experience [[altitude sickness|mountain sickness]], which is a type of [[hypoxia (medical)|hypoxia]], a clinical syndrome of severe lack of oxygen. Complications include [[fatigue (medical)|fatigue]], [[dizziness]], [[breathlessness]], [[headaches]], [[insomnia]], [[malaise]], [[nausea]], [[vomiting]], [[cramp|body pain]], [[Anorexia (symptom)|loss of appetite]], [[Tinnitus|ear-ringing]], [[frost bite|blistering]] and [[cyanosis|purpling of the hands and feet]], and [[vasodilation|dilated veins]].<ref name=pen>{{cite journal |author=Penaloza D, Arias-Stella J| title=The heart and pulmonary circulation at high altitudes: healthy highlanders and chronic mountain sickness |journal=Circulation |volume=115 |issue=9 |pages=1132–1146|year=2007 |url=http://circ.ahajournals.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=17339571 |pmid=17339571 |doi=10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.106.624544| last2=Arias-Stella }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=León-Velarde F, Villafuerte FC, Richalet JP | title=Chronic mountain sickness and the heart |journal=Prog Cardiovasc Dis |volume=52 | issue=6 |pages=540–549 |year=2010 |doi=10.1016/j.pcad.2010.02.012 |pmid=20417348| last2=Villafuerte | last3=Richalet }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Wheatley K, Creed M, Mellor A | title=Haematological changes at altitude |journal=J R Army Med Corps|volume=157 | issue=1 |pages=38–42 |year=2011 |doi=10.1136/jramc-157-01-07|pmid=21465909| last2=Creed | last3=Mellor }}</ref>
The sickness is compounded by related symptoms such as [[high altitude cerebral edema|cerebral oedema (swelling of brain)]] and [[high altitude pulmonary edema|pulmonary oedema (fluid accumulation in lungs)]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Paralikar SJ| title=High altitude pulmonary edema-clinical features, pathophysiology, prevention and treatment |journal=Indian J Occup Environ Med |volume=16| issue=2|pages=59–62 |year=2012|doi=10.4103/0019-5278.107066 |pmid=23580834| pmc=3617508 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Eide RP 3rd, Asplund CA | title=Altitude illness: update on prevention and treatment |journal=Curr Sports Med Rep |volume=11| issue=3|pages=124–30 |year=2012 |doi=10.1249/JSR.0b013e3182563e7a |pmid=22580489 | last2=Asplund }}</ref> For several days, they [[hyperventilation|breathe excessively]] and [[hypermetabolism|burn extra energy]] even when the body is [[basal metabolic rate|relaxed]]. The [[heart rate]] then gradually decreases. Hypoxia, in fact, is one of the principal causes of death among mountaineers.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Huey RB, Eguskitza X, Dillon M| title=Mountaineering in thin air. Patterns of death and of weather at high altitude |journal=Adv Exp Med Biol |volume=502 |issue=|pages=225–336|year=2001 |pmid=11950141 |doi=| last2=Eguskitza | last3=Dillon }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Firth PG, Zheng H, Windsor JS, Sutherland AI, Imray CH, Moore GW, Semple JL, Roach RC, Salisbury RA| title=Mortality on Mount Everest, 1921-2006: descriptive study |journal=British Medical Journal |volume=337|issue=|pages=a2654|year=2008 |pmid=19074222 |pmc=2602730 |doi=10.1136/bmj.a2654| last2=Zheng | last3=Windsor | last4=Sutherland | last5=Imray | last6=Moore | last7=Semple | last8=Roach | last9=Salisbury }}</ref> In women, pregnancy can be severely affected, such as development of [[hypertension|high blood pressure]], called [[preeclampsia]], which causes [[preterm birth|premature labour]], [[low birth weight]] of babies, and often [[complications of pregnancy|complicated]] with [[haemorrhage|profuse bleeding]], [[seizures]], and [[maternal death|death of the mother]].<ref name=fris /><ref>{{cite journal |author=Moore LG, Shriver M, Bemis L, Hickler B, Wilson M, Brutsaert T, Parra E, Vargas E| title=Maternal adaptation to high altitude pregnancy An experiment of nature A review |journal=Placenta |volume=25 |issue=suppl | pages=S60–S71 |year=2004 |doi=10.1016/j.placenta.2004.01.008| last2=Shriver | last3=Bemis | last4=Hickler | last5=Wilson | last6=Brutsaert | last7=Parra | last8=Vargas | pmid=15033310}}</ref>
More than 140 million people worldwide are estimated to live at an elevation higher than {{convert|2500|m|ft}} above sea level, of which 13 million are in Ethiopia, 1.7 million in Tibet (total of 78 million in [[Asia]]), 35 million in the South American Andes, and 0.3 million in [[Colorado]] [[Rocky Mountains]].<ref name=hor>{{cite book|vauthors=Hornbein T, Schoene R |year=2001|title=High Altitude: An Exploration of Human Adaptation (Lung Biology in Health and Disease Volume 161)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=P1clQRmZk1AC&printsec |publisher=Marcel Dekker, New York, USA |pages=42–874 |isbn=082474604X}}</ref> Certain natives of Tibet, Ethiopia, and the Andes have been living at these high altitudes for generations and are protected from hypoxia as a consequence of genetic adaptation.<ref name=moor/><ref name=pen /> It is estimated that at {{convert|4000|m|ft}}, every [[lung volumes|lungful of air]] only has 60% of the oxygen molecules that people at sea level have.<ref name=hor /> At elevations above {{convert|7600|m|ft}}, [[hypoxia (medical)|lack of oxygen]] becomes seriously lethal. That is, these highlanders are constantly exposed to an intolerably low oxygen environment, yet they live without any debilitating problems.<ref name=mue/> Basically, the shared adaptation is the ability to maintain relatively low levels of [[haemoglobin]], which is the [[protein|chemical complex]] for [[circulatory system|transporting oxygen in the blood]].<ref name=moo /> One of the best documented effects of high altitude is a progressive reduction in [[birth weight]]. It has been known that women of long-resident high-altitude population are not affected. These women are known to give birth to heavier-weight infants than women of lowland inhabitants. This is particularly true among Tibetan babies, whose average birth weight is 294-650 (~470) g heavier than the surrounding [[chinese people|Chinese population]]; and their [[oxygen saturation|blood-oxygen level]] is considerably higher.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Niermeyer S, Yang P, Shanmina, Drolkar, Zhuang J, Moore LG|year=1995 |title=Arterial oxygen saturation in Tibetan and Han infants born in Lhasa, Tibet| url=http://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJM199511093331903 |journal=The New England Journal of Medicine |volume=333 |issue=9 |pages=1248–1252|pmid=7566001|doi=10.1056/NEJM199511093331903 }}</ref>
The first scientific investigations of high-altitude adaptation was done by [[A. Roberto Frisancho]] of the [[University of Michigan]] in the late 1960s among the [[Quechua people]] of Peru.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Frisancho AR |title=Human growth and pulmonary function of a high altitude Peruvian Quechua population |journal=Hum Biol |volume= 41|issue=3 | pages=365–379 |year=1969 |pmid=5372293|jstor=41435777 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Leonard WR |title=Contributions of A. Roberto Frisancho to human population biology: An introduction |journal=American Journal of Human Biology |volume=21 |issue=5 | pages=599–605 |year=2009 |pmid=19367580|doi=10.1002/ajhb.20916}}</ref> [[Paul T. Baker]], [[Pennsylvania State University|Penn State University]], (in the [http://anth.la.psu.edu/ Department of Anthropology]) also conducted a considerable amount of research into human adaptation to high altitudes, and mentored students who continued this research.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasonline.org/member-directory/deceased-members/58048.html|title=Paul Baker|last=http://www.nasonline.org|first=National Academy of Sciences -|website=www.nasonline.org|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref> One of these students went on to conduct research on high altitude adaptation among the Tibetans in the early 1980s through to today, anthropologist [[Cynthia Beall]] of the [[Case Western Reserve University]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Beall C |title=Human adaptability studies at high altitude: Research designs and major concepts during fifty years of discovery |journal=Am J Hum Biol |volume=25|issue=2 | pages=141–147 |year=2013 |pmid=23349118 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.22355}}</ref>
==Physiological basis==
===Tibetans=== [[File:Sherpa.jpg|200px|thumb|right| A Sherpa family]]
Scientists started to notice the extraordinary physical performance of Tibetans since the beginning of Himalayan climbing era in the early 20th century. The hypothesis of a possible evolutionary genetic adaptation makes sense.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wu T, Kayser B |title=High altitude adaptation in Tibetans |journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=7 |issue=3 | pages=193–208 |year=2006 |pmid=16978132 |doi=10.1089/ham.2006.7.193|last2=Kayser }}</ref> The [[Tibetan plateau]] has an average elevation of {{convert|4000|m|ft}} above sea level, and covering more than 2.5 million km, it is the highest and largest [[plateau]] in the world. In 1990, it was estimated that 4,594,188 Tibetans live on the plateau, with 53% living at an altitude over {{convert|3500|m|ft}}. Fairly large numbers (about 600,000) live at an altitude exceeding {{convert|4500|m|ft}} in the Chantong-Qingnan area.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Wu T|year=2001 |title=The Qinghai-Tibetan plateau: how high do Tibetans live?| journal=High Alt Med Biol|volume=2|issue=4 |pages=489–499|pmid=11809089 |doi=10.1089/152702901753397054}}</ref> Where the Tibetan highlanders live, the oxygen level is only about 60% of that at sea level. The Tibetans, who have been living in this region for 3,000 years, do not exhibit the elevated haemoglobin concentrations to cope with oxygen deficiency as observed in other populations who have moved temporarily or permanently at high altitudes. Instead, the Tibetans inhale more air with each breath and breathe more rapidly than either sea-level populations or Andeans. Tibetans have better [[oxygenation (medical)|oxygenation]] at birth, enlarged lung volumes throughout life, and a higher capacity for [[physical exercise|exercise]]. They show a sustained increase in [[brain|cerebral]] blood flow, lower haemoglobin concentration, and less susceptibility to [[chronic mountain sickness]] than other populations, due to their longer history of high-altitude habitation.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Moore LG, Niermeyer S, Zamudio S |year=1998 |title=Human adaptation to high altitude: Regional and life-cycle perspectives |journal=Am J Phys Anthropol |volume=107 |pages=25–64 |pmid=9881522 | doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-8644(1998)107:27+<25::AID-AJPA3>3.0.CO;2-L |last2=Niermeyer |last3=Zamudio}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |first=Lorna G|last=Moore |year=2001 |title=Human genetic adaptation to high altitude|journal=High Altitude Medicine & Biology |volume=2 |issue=2 |pages=257–279 |pmid=11443005| doi=10.1089/152702901750265341}}</ref>
General people can develop short-term tolerance with careful physical preparation and systematic monitoring of movements, but the biological changes are quite temporary and reversible when they return to lowlands.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Muza SR, Beidleman BA, Fulco CS|year=2010 |title=Altitude preexposure recommendations for inducing acclimatization| journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=11|issue=2|pages=87–92|pmid=20586592 |doi=10.1089/ham.2010.1006 |last2=Beidleman |last3=Fulco }}</ref> Moreover, unlike lowland people who only experience [[hyperventilation|increased breathing]] for a few days after entering high altitudes, Tibetans retain this rapid breathing and elevated lung-capacity throughout their lifetime.<ref name=beall07>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM |year=2007 |title=Two routes to functional adaptation: Tibetan and Andean high-altitude natives | journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A|volume=14|issue=Suppl 1 |pages=8655–8660|pmid=17494744 |pmc=1876443 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0701985104|bibcode=2007PNAS..104.8655B }}</ref> This enables them to inhale larger amounts of air per unit of time to compensate for low oxygen levels. In addition, they have high levels (mostly double) of [[nitric oxide]] in their blood, when compared to lowlanders, and this probably helps their blood vessels [[vasodilation|dilate]] for enhanced [[blood circulation]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Beall CM, Laskowski D, Erzurum SC|year=2012 |title=Nitric oxide in adaptation to altitude |journal=Free Radic Biol Med |volume=52 |issue=7 |pages=1123–1134 |pmid=22300645 |pmc=3295887 |doi=10.1016/j.freeradbiomed.2011.12.028|last2=Laskowski |last3=Erzurum }}</ref> Further, their haemoglobin level is not significantly different (average 15.6 g/dl in males and 14.2 g/dl in females),<ref name=beall1998>{{cite journal|last1=Beall|first1=Cynthia M.|last2=Brittenham|first2=Gary M.|last3=Strohl|first3=Kingman P.|last4=Blangero|first4=John|last5=Williams-Blangero|first5=Sarah|last6=Goldstein|first6=Melvyn C.|last7=Decker|first7=Michael J.|last8=Vargas|first8=Enrique|last9=Villena|first9=Mercedes|last10=Soria|first10=Rudy|last11=Alarcon|first11=Ana Maria|last12=Gonzales|first12=Cristina|display-authors=8|title=Hemoglobin concentration of high-altitude Tibetans and Bolivian Aymara|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|date=1998|volume=106|issue=3|pages=385–400|doi=10.1002/(SICI)1096-8644(199807)106:3<385::AID-AJPA10>3.0.CO;2-X|pmid=9696153}}</ref> from those of people living at low altitude. (Normally, mountaineers experience >2 g/dl increase in Hb level at Mt. Everest base camp in two weeks.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Windsor|first1=J. S|last2=Rodway|first2=G. W |title=Heights and haematology: the story of haemoglobin at altitude |journal=Postgraduate Medical Journal |date=2007 |volume=83 |issue=977 |pages=148–151 |doi=10.1136/pgmj.2006.049734 |pmid=17344565 |pmc=2599997}}</ref>) In this way they are able to evade both the effects of hypoxia and mountain sickness throughout life. Even when they climbed the highest summits like Mt. Everest, they showed regular oxygen uptake, greater ventilation, more brisk hypoxic ventilatory responses, larger lung volumes, greater diffusing capacities, constant body weight and a better quality of sleep, compared to people from the lowland.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Wu T, Li S, Ward MP |year=2005 |title=Tibetans at extreme altitude| journal=Wilderness Environ Med |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=47–54 |pmid=15813148 |doi=10.1580/pr04-04.1|last2=Li |last3=Ward }}</ref>
===Andeans===
In contrast to the Tibetans, the Andean highlanders, who have been living at high-altitudes for no more than 11,000 years, show different pattern of haemoglobin adaptation. Their haemoglobin concentration is higher compared to those of lowlander population, which also happens to lowlanders moving to high altitude. When they spend some weeks in the lowland their haemoglobin drops to average of other people. This shows only temporary and reversible acclimatisation. However, in contrast to lowland people, they do have increased oxygen level in their haemoglobin, that is, more oxygen per blood volume than other people. This confers an ability to carry more oxygen in each red blood cell, making a more effective transport of oxygen in their body, while their breathing is essentially at the same rate.<ref name=beall07 /> This enables them to overcome hypoxia and normally reproduce without risk of death for the mother or baby. The Andean highlanders are known from the 16th-century missionaries that their reproduction had always been normal, without any effect in the [[fecundity|giving birth]] or the risk for early pregnancy loss, which are common to hypoxic stress.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Vitzthum |first1=Virginia J. |title=Fifty fertile years: anthropologists' studies of reproduction in high altitude natives |journal=American Journal of Human Biology |year=2013 |volume=25 |issue=2 |pages=179–189 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.22357 |pmid=23382088}}</ref> They have developmentally acquired enlarged residual lung volume and its associated increase in [[alveolus|alveolar]] area, which are supplemented with increased tissue thickness and moderate increase in [[red blood cells]]. Though the physical growth in body size is [[stunted growth|delayed]], growth in lung volumes is accelerated.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Frisancho|first1=A. Roberto|title=Developmental functional adaptation to high altitude: review|journal=American Journal of Human Biology|date=2013|volume=25|issue=2|pages=151–168|doi=10.1002/ajhb.22367|pmid=24065360}}</ref> An incomplete adaptation such as elevated haemoglobin levels still leaves them at risk for mountain sickness with old age. For example, among four quantitative features, such as are resting ventilation, hypoxic ventilatory response, oxygen saturation, and haemoglobin concentration, the levels of variations are significantly different between the Tibetans and the Aymaras.<ref name=bea00>{{cite journal| author=Beall CM |year=2000 |title=Tibetan and Andean patterns of adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia|journal=Hum Biol|volume=72 |issue=1 |pages=201–228 |pmid=10721618|doi=}}</ref> The Andeans, in general are the most poorly adapted, as particularly shown by their frequent mountain sickness and loss of adaptative characters when they move to lowlands.<ref>{{cite journal| author=Xing G, Qualls C, Huicho L, Rivera-Ch M, Stobdan T, Slessarev M, Prisman E, Ito S, Wu H, Norboo A, Dolma D, Kunzang M, Norboo T, Gamboa JL, Claydon VE, Fisher J, Zenebe G, Gebremedhin A, Hainsworth R, Verma A, Appenzeller O|year=2008 |title=Adaptation and mal-adaptation to ambient hypoxia; Andean, Ethiopian and Himalayan patterns|url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0002342 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=3 |issue=6 |pages=e2342 |pmid=18523639 |pmc=2396283 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0002342|last2=Qualls |last3=Huicho |last4=Rivera-Ch |last5=Stobdan |last6=Slessarev |last7=Prisman |last8=Ito |last9=Wu |last10=Norboo |last11=Dolma |last12=Kunzang |last13=Norboo |last14=Gamboa |last15=Claydon |last16=Fisher |last17=Zenebe |last18=Gebremedhin |last19=Hainsworth |last20=Verma |last21=Appenzeller |bibcode=2008PLoSO...3.2342X }}</ref>
===Ethiopians===
The peoples of the [[Ethiopian highlands]] also live at extremely high altitudes, around {{convert|3000|m|ft}} to {{convert|3500|m|ft}}. Highland Ethiopians exhibit elevated haemoglobin levels, like Andeans and lowlander peoples at high altitudes, but do not exhibit the Andean’s increased in oxygen-content of haemoglobin.<ref>{{cite journal| author =Beall CM |year=2006|title=Andean, Tibetan, and Ethiopian patterns of adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia |journal=Integr Comp Biol |volume=46 |issue=1 |pages=18–24 |pmid=21672719 |doi=10.1093/icb/icj004}}</ref> Among healthy individuals, the average haemoglobin concentrations are 15.9 and 15.0 g/dl for males and females respectively (which is lower than normal, almost similar to the Tibetans), and an average oxygen saturation of haemoglobin is 95.3% (which is higher than average, like the Andeans).<ref>{{cite journal| author=Beall CM, Decker MJ, Brittenham GM, Kushner I, Gebremedhin A, Strohl KP |year=2002 |title=An Ethiopian pattern of human adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A |volume=99 |issue=26 |pages=17215–17218 |pmid=12471159 |pmc=139295 |doi=10.1073/pnas.252649199 |last2=Decker |last3=Brittenham |last4=Kushner |last5=Gebremedhin |last6=Strohl |bibcode=2002PNAS...9917215B}}</ref> Additionally, Ethiopian highlanders do not exhibit any significant change in blood circulation of the brain, which has been observed among the Peruvian highlanders (and attributed to their frequent altitude-related illnesses).<ref>{{cite journal| author=Claydon VE, Gulli G, Slessarev M, Appenzeller O, Zenebe G, Gebremedhin A, Hainsworth R |year=2008|title=Cerebrovascular responses to hypoxia and hypocapnia in Ethiopian high altitude dwellers |journal=Stroke |volume=39 |issue=2|pages=336–342 |pmid=18096845 |doi=10.1161/STROKEAHA.107.491498|last2=Gulli|last3=Slessarev|last4=Appenzeller|last5=Zenebe|last6=Gebremedhin|last7=Hainsworth}}</ref> Yet, similar to the Andeans and Tibetans, the Ethiopian highlanders are immune to the extreme dangers posed by high-altitude environment, and their pattern of adaptation is definitely unique from that of other highland peoples.<ref name=hor />
==Genetic basis==
The underlying [[molecular evolution]] of high-altitude adaptation has been explored and understood fairly recently.<ref name=mue /> Depending on the geographical and environmental pressures, high-altitude adaptation involves different genetic patterns, some of which have evolved quite recently. For example, Tibetan adaptations became prevalent in the past 3,000 years, a rapid example of [[recent human evolution]]. At the turn of the 21st century, it was reported that the genetic make-up of the respiratory components of the Tibetan and the Ethiopian populations are significantly different.<ref name=bea00 />
=== Tibetans ===
Substantial evidence in Tibetan highlanders suggests that variation in haemoglobin and [[oxygen saturation|blood-oxygen]] levels are adaptive as [[Fitness (biology)|Darwinian fitness]]. It has been documented that Tibetan women with a high likelihood of possessing one to two [[allele]]s for high blood-oxygen content (which is odd for normal women) had more surviving children; the higher the oxygen capacity, the lower the infant mortality.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Beall CM, Song K, Elston RC, Goldstein MC |year=2004 |title=Higher offspring survival among Tibetan women with high oxygen saturation genotypes residing at {{convert|4000|m|ft}}| url=http://www.pnas.org/content/101/39/14300 |journal=Proc Natl Acad Sci U S A |volume=101|issue=39 |pages=14300–14304 |pmid=15353580|pmc=521103 |doi=10.1073/pnas.0405949101|last2=Song |last3=Elston |last4=Goldstein |bibcode=2004PNAS..10114300B }}</ref> In 2010, for the first time, the genes responsible for the unique adaptive traits were identified following genome sequences of 50 Tibetans and 40 [[Han Chinese]] from [[Beijing]]. Initially, the strongest signal of natural selection detected was a transcription factor involved in response to hypoxia, called endothelial Per-Arnt-Sim (PAS) domain protein 1 (''[[EPAS1]]''). It was found that one [[single-nucleotide polymorphism]] (SNP) at ''EPAS1'' shows a 78% frequency difference between Tibetan and mainland Chinese samples, representing the fastest genetic change observed in any human gene to date. Hence, Tibetan adaptation to high altitude becomes the fastest process of [[phenotype|phenotypically observable]] evolution in humans,<ref>{{cite web|author1=Native Village Youth |author2=Education news |title=Tibetans evolved at fastest pace ever measured |url=http://www.nativevillage.org/Archives/2011%20Archives/MAY%202011%20News/Tibetans%20Evolved%20at%20Fastest%20Pace%20Ever%20Measured.htm | date=May 2011|accessdate=2013-04-15}}</ref> which is estimated to occur in less than 3,000 years ago, when the Tibetans split up from the mainland Chinese population.<ref name=yi /> [[Mutations]] in ''EPAS1'', at higher frequency in Tibetans than their Han neighbours, correlate with decreased haemoglobin concentrations among the Tibetans, which is the hallmark of their adaptation to hypoxia. Simultaneously, two genes, egl nine homolog 1 (''[[EGLN1]]'') (which inhibits haemoglobin production under high oxygen concentration) and peroxisome proliferator-activated receptor alpha (''[[PPARA]]''), were also identified to be positively selected in relation to decreased haemoglobin nature in the Tibetans.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Simonson TS, Yang Y, Huff CD, Yun H, Qin G, Witherspoon DJ, Bai Z, Lorenzo FR, Xing J, Jorde LB, Prchal JT, Ge R |year=2010 |title=Genetic evidence for high-altitude adaptation in Tibet | url=http://www.sciencemag.org/content/329/5987/72 |journal=Science |volume=329 |issue=5987|pages=72–75 |pmid=20466884 |doi=10.1126/science.1189406|last2=Yang |last3=Huff |last4=Yun |last5=Qin |last6=Witherspoon |last7=Bai |last8=Lorenzo |last9=Xing |last10=Jorde |last11=Prchal |last12=Ge |bibcode=2010Sci...329...72S }}</ref>
Similarly, the [[Sherpas]], known for their Himalayan hardiness, exhibit similar patterns in the ''EPAS1'' gene, which further fortifies that the gene is under [[Selection (biology)|selection]] for adaptation to the high-altitude life of Tibetans.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Hanaoka M, Droma Y, Basnyat B, Ito M, Kobayashi N, Katsuyama Y, Kubo K, Ota M |year=2012 |title=Genetic variants in EPAS1 contribute to adaptation to high-altitude hypoxia in Sherpas | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0050566 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7 |issue=12|pages=e50566|pmid=23227185 |pmc=3515610|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0050566|last2=Droma |last3=Basnyat |last4=Ito |last5=Kobayashi |last6=Katsuyama |last7=Kubo |last8=Ota |bibcode=2012PLoSO...750566H }}</ref> A study in 2014 indicates that the mutant ''[[EPAS1]]'' gene could have been inherited from archaic [[hominin]]s, the [[Denisovans]].<ref name="Huerta-Sanchez et al. 2014">{{cite journal |last1=Huerta-Sánchez|first1=Emilia |last2=Jin |first2=Xin |last3=Asan |last4=Bianba |first4=Zhuoma|last5=Peter|first5=Benjamin M. |last6=Vinckenbosch|first6=Nicolas|last7=Liang|first7=Yu|last8=Yi|first8=Xin|last9=He|first9=Mingze|last10=Somel|first10=Mehmet|last11=Ni|first11=Peixiang|last12=Wang|first12=Bo|last13=Ou|first13=Xiaohua|last14=Huasang|last15=Luosang|first15=Jiangbai|last16=Cuo|first16=Zha |last24=Li |first24=Yingrui |last25=Wang |first25=Jian |last26=Wang |first26=Jun |last27=Nielsen |first27=Rasmus |title=Altitude adaptation in Tibetans caused by introgression of Denisovan-like DNA |journal=Nature |date=2014 |volume=512 |issue=7513 |pages=194–197 |doi=10.1038/nature13408 |pmid=25043035 |bibcode=2014Natur.512..194H |display-authors=8 |pmc=4134395}}</ref> ''EPAS1'' and ''EGLN1'' Ouzhuluobu, Basang, Ciwangsangbu, Danzengduojie, Chen H, Shi H, Su B|year=2011 |title=Genetic variations in Tibetan populations and high-altitude adaptation at the Himalayas | |last4=Cui |last5=Qi |last6=Luo |last7=Tao |last8=Wu |last13=Chen |last14=Shi |last15=Su }}</ref> Comparative genome analysis in 2014 revealed that the Tibetans inherited an equal mixture of genomes from the Nepalese-Sherpas and Hans, and they acquired the adaptive genes from the sherpa-lineage. Further, the population split was estimated to occur around 20,000 to 40,000 years ago, a range of which support archaeological, mitochondria DNA and Y chromosome evidence for an initial colonisation of the Tibetan plateau around 30,000 years ago.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Jeong |first1=Choongwon |last2=Alkorta-Aranburu |first2=Gorka |last3=Basnyat |first3=Buddha |last4=Neupane|first4=Maniraj |last5=Witonsky |first5=David B. |last6=Pritchard|first6=Jonathan K. |last7=Beall |first7=Cynthia M. |last8=Di Rienzo|first8=Anna |title=Admixture facilitates genetic adaptations to high altitude in Tibet|journal=Nature Communications |year=2014 |volume=5 |issue=3281 |doi=10.1038/ncomms4281|pmid=24513612|pages=3281|bibcode=2014NatCo...5E3281J}}</ref>
The genes (''EPAS1'', ''EGLN1'', and ''PPARA'') function in concert with another gene named [[hypoxia inducible factors]] (''HIF''), which in turn is a principal regulator of red blood cell production ([[erythropoiesis]]) in response to oxygen metabolism.<ref>{{cite journal |author=MacInnis MJ, Rupert JL |year=2011 |title='ome on the Range: altitude adaptation, positive selection, and Himalayan genomics | journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=12 |issue=2 |pages=133–139|pmid=21718161 |doi=10.1089/ham.2010.1090|last2=Rupert }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=van Patot MC, Gassmann M |year=2011 |title=Hypoxia: adapting to high altitude by mutating EPAS-1, the gene encoding HIF-2α | journal=High Alt Med Biol |volume=12|issue=2|pages=157–167|pmid=21718164 |doi=10.1089/ham.2010.1099|last2=Gassmann }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |author=Simonson TS, McClain DA, Jorde LB, Prchal JT |year=2012 |title=Genetic determinants of Tibetan high-altitude adaptation | journal=Human Genetics |volume=131|issue=4|pages=527–533|pmid=22068265 |doi=10.1007/s00439-011-1109-3|last2=McClain |last3=Jorde |last4=Prchal }}</ref> The genes are associated not only with decreased haemoglobin levels, but also in regulating energy metabolism. ''EPAS1'' is significantly associated with increased lactate concentration (the product of [[anaerobic glycolysis]]), and ''PPARA'' is correlated with decrease in the activity of [[fatty acid oxidation]].<ref>{{cite journal |author=Ge RL, Simonson TS, Cooksey RC, Tanna U, Qin G, Huff CD, Witherspoon DJ, Xing J, Zhengzhong B, Prchal JT, Jorde LB, McClain DA |year=2012 |title=Metabolic insight into mechanisms of high-altitude adaptation in Tibetans | journal=Mol Genet Metab |volume=106|issue=2|pages=244–247 |pmid=22503288 |pmc=3437309 |doi=10.1016/j.ymgme.2012.03.003 |last2=Simonson |last3=Cooksey |last4=Tanna |last5=Qin |last6=Huff |last7=Witherspoon |last8=Xing |last9=Zhengzhong |last10=Prchal |last11=Jorde |last12=McClain }}</ref> ''EGLN1'' codes for an enzyme, prolyl hydroxylase 2 (PHD2), involved in erythropoiesis. Among the Tibetans, mutation in ''EGLN1'' (specifically at position 12, where cytosine is replaced with guanine; and at 380, where G is replaced with C) results in mutant PHD2 (aspartic acid at position 4 becomes glutamine, and cysteine at 127 becomes serine) and this mutation inhibits erythropoiesis. The mutation is estimated to occur about 8,000 years ago.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lorenzo|first1=Felipe R|last2=Huff|first2=Chad|last3=Myllymäki|first3=Mikko|last4=Olenchock|first4=Benjamin|last5=Swierczek|first5=Sabina|last6=Tashi|first6=Tsewang|last7=Gordeuk|first7=Victor|last8=Wuren|first8=Tana|last9=Ri-Li|first9=Ge|last10=McClain|first10=Donald A|last11=Khan|first11=Tahsin M|last12=Koul|first12=Parvaiz A|last13=Guchhait|first13=Prasenjit|last14=Salama|first14=Mohamed E|last15=Xing|first15=Jinchuan|last16=Semenza|first16=Gregg L|last17=Liberzon|first17=Ella|last18=Wilson|first18=Andrew|last19=Simonson|first19=Tatum S|last20=Jorde|first20=Lynn B|last21=Kaelin|first21=William G|last22=Koivunen|first22=Peppi|last23=Prchal|first23=Josef T|title=A genetic mechanism for Tibetan high-altitude adaptation|journal=Nature Genetics|year=2014|volume=46|doi=10.1038/ng.3067|pmid=25129147|issue=9|pages=951–6|pmc=4473257}}</ref> Further, the Tibetans are enriched for genes in the disease class of human reproduction (such as genes from the ''[[DAZ associated protein 1|DAZ]]'', ''[[BPY2]]'', ''[[CDY1|CDY]]'', and ''[[HLA-DQ]]'' and ''[[HLA-DR]]'' gene clusters) and biological process categories of response to [[DNA damage]] stimulus and [[DNA repair]] (such as ''[[RAD51]]'', ''[[RAD52]]'', and ''[[MRE11A]]''), which are related to the adaptive traits of high infant birth weight and [[melanism|darker skin tone]] and are most likely due to recent local adaptation.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Zhang YB, Li X, Zhang F, Wang DM, Yu J|year=2012 |title=A preliminary study of copy number variation in Tibetans | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0041768 |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=7|issue=7|pages=e41768|pmid=22844521| pmc=3402393 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0041768|last2=Li |last3=Zhang |last4=Wang |last5=Yu |bibcode=2012PLoSO...741768Z }}</ref>
===Andeans===
The patterns of genetic adaptation among the Andeans are largely distinct from those of the Tibetan, with both populations showing evidence of positive natural selection in different genes or gene regions. However, ''EGLN1'' appears to be the principal signature of evolution, as it shows evidence of positive selection in both Tibetans and Andeans. Even then, the pattern of variation for this gene differs between the two populations.<ref name=bigh /> Among the Andeans, there are no significant associations between ''EPAS1'' or ''EGLN1'' SNP [[genotype]]s and haemoglobin concentration, which has been the characteristic of the Tibetans.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Bigham AW, Wilson MJ, Julian CG, Kiyamu M, Vargas E, Leon-Velarde F, Rivera-Chira M, Rodriquez C, Browne VA, Parra E, Brutsaert TD, Moore LG, Shriver MD |year=2013 |title=Andean and Tibetan patterns of adaptation to high altitude | journal=Am J Hum Biol|volume=25|issue=2|pages=190–197|pmid=23348729 |doi=10.1002/ajhb.22358|last2=Wilson |last3=Julian |last4=Kiyamu |last5=Vargas |last6=Leon-Velarde |last7=Rivera-Chira |last8=Rodriquez |last9=Browne |last10=Parra |last11=Brutsaert |last12=Moore |last13=Shriver }}</ref> The whole genome sequences of 20 Andeans (half of them having chronic mountain sickness) revealed that two genes, SENP1 (an erythropoiesis regulator) and ANP32D (an oncogene) play vital roles in their weak adaptation to hypoxia.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Zhou D, Udpa N, Ronen R, Stobdan T, Liang J, Appenzeller O, Zhao HW, Yin Y, Du Y, Guo L, Cao R, Wang Y, Jin X, Huang C, Jia W, Cao D, Guo G, Gamboa JL, Villafuerte F, Callacondo D, Xue J, Liu S, Frazer KA, Li Y, Bafna V, Haddad GG |title=Whole-genome sequencing uncovers the genetic basis of chronic mountain sickness in Andean highlanders |journal=Am J Hum Genet |volume=93|issue=S0002–9297(13)00331–5 | pages=452–62|year=2013 |pmid=23954164 |pmc=3769925 |doi=10.1016/j.ajhg.2013.07.011|last2=Udpa |last3=Ronen |last4=Stobdan |last5=Liang |last6=Appenzeller |last7=Zhao |last8=Yin |last9=Du |last10=Guo |last11=Cao |last12=Wang |last13=Jin |last14=Huang |last15=Jia |last16=Cao |last17=Guo |last18=Gamboa |last19=Villafuerte |last20=Callacondo |last21=Xue |last22=Liu |last23=Frazer |last24=Li |last25=Bafna |last26=Haddad }}</ref>
===Ethiopians===
The adaptive mechanism of Ethiopian highlanders is quite different. This is probably because their migration to the highland was relatively early; for example, the [[amhara people|Amhara]] have inhabited altitudes above {{convert|2500|m|ft}} for at least 5,000 years and altitudes around {{convert|2000|m|ft}} to {{convert|2400|m|ft}} for more than 70,000 years.<ref>{{cite journal|year=2006|title=Human technical behavior in the African Middle Stone Age: The lithic assemblange of Porc-Epic Cave (Dire Dawa, Ethiopia)|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10437-006-9000-7|journal=African Archaeological Review|volume=22|issue=4|pages=177–197|doi=10.1007/s10437-006-9000-7|pmid=|author=Pleurdeau D}}</ref> Genomic analysis of two ethnic groups, Amhara and [[oromo people|Oromo]], revealed that gene variations associated with haemoglobin difference among Tibetans or other variants at the same [[locus (genetics)|gene location]] do not influence the adaptation in Ethiopians.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Alkorta-Aranburu G, Beall CM, Witonsky DB, Gebremedhin A, Pritchard JK, Di Rienzo A|year=2012 |title=The genetic architecture of adaptations to high altitude in Ethiopia | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1003110 |journal=PLOS Genetics |volume=8|issue=12|pages=e1003110|pmid=23236293| pmc=3516565 |doi=10.1371/journal.pgen.1003110|last2=Beall |last3=Witonsky |last4=Gebremedhin |last5=Pritchard |last6=Di Rienzo }}</ref> Identification of specific genes further reveals that several candidate genes are involved in Ethiopians, including ''[[CBARA1]]'', ''[[VAV3]]'', ''[[ARNT2]]'' and ''[[THRB]]''. Two of these genes (''THRB'' and ''ARNT2'') are known to play a role in the [[Hypoxia-inducible factors|HIF-1 pathway]], a pathway implicated in previous work reported in Tibetan and Andean studies. This supports the concept that adaptation to high altitude arose independently among different highlanders as a result of [[convergent evolution]].<ref>{{cite journal|author=Scheinfeldt LB, Soi S, Thompson S, Ranciaro A, Woldemeskel D, Beggs W, Lambert C, Jarvis JP, Abate D, Belay G, Tishkoff SA|year=2012 |title=Genetic adaptation to high altitude in the Ethiopian highlands | url=http://dx.plos.org/10.1371/journal.pgen.1003110 |journal=Genome Biol |volume=13|issue=1|pages=R1 |pmid=22264333| pmc=3334582 |doi=10.1186/gb-2012-13-1-r1|last2=Soi |last3=Thompson |last4=Ranciaro |last5=Woldemeskel |last6=Beggs |last7=Lambert |last8=Jarvis |last9=Abate |last10=Belay |last11=Tishkoff }}</ref>

{{One source|date=October 2015}}{{Orphan|date=December 2012}} {{Infobox University |name = International Program of Psycho-Social Health Research |image_name = IPP-SHR Logo.png |image_size = 250px |established = 2006 |city = [[Brisbane, Queensland|Brisbane]] (Headquarters) |state = [[Queensland]] |country = [[Australia]] |nickname = IPP-SHR |address = |publictransit = |telephone = |coor = |logo = }} '''International Program of Psycho-Social Health Research''' ('''IPP-SHR''') is an Australian research program based in [[Queensland]] which explores the psycho-social dimension of health through examining and reporting on the human experience of serious physical and mental illnesses.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|title = ISSUU - IPP-SHR, CQUniversity|url = http://issuu.com/ipp-shr|website = issuu.com|accessdate = 2015-10-14}}</ref>
== History ==
The International Program for Psycho Social Health was established in 2006 by A/Pr Pam McGrath<ref>{{Cite journal|url = https://www.nhmrc.gov.au/_files_nhmrc/file/grants/dataset/2015/12d_nhmrc_end_of_grant_report_summaries_cancer_2004_to_2013.docx|title = NHMRC Research Achievements - SUMMARY|last = Faulkner|first = Matthew|date = 13 January 2015|journal = |doi = |pmid = |access-date = 14 January 2015|publisher = [[NHMRC]]|format=docx}}</ref> as a research initiative funded by the [[National Health and Medical Research Council]] (NHMRC) and [[CQUniversity]].<ref name=":0" /> In 2011, the International Program of Psycho-Social Health Research moved to Griffith Health Institute, Griffith University.
== Areas of research == IPP-SHR explores the psycho-social dimension of health through a wide range of topics including: palliative care; haematology/oncology; mental health; acute medicine; bioethics; rural and remote health; Indigenous health; spirituality; paediatrics; birth studies; and service delivery evaluation.<ref name=":0" />
IPP-SHR also produces two industry focused publications including a quarterly review and a weekly podcast.
== References== {{reflist|30em}}
