{{Infobox Organization |name = Oxford Brookes Centre for Nutrition and Health |logo = [[Image:Oxford-Brookes-University-Logo.svg|220px|Functional Food Centre, Oxford Brookes University]] |established = 2009 |type = Research centre |founder = Jeya Henry<ref name=about/> | leader_title = Director | leader_name = Helen Lightowler<ref name=staff>{{cite web|title=Centre staff|url=https://www.brookes.ac.uk/shssw/nutrition/research/oxbcnh/members/|website=Oxford Brookes Centre for Nutrition and Health|publisher=Oxford Brookes University|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref> |city = [[Oxford]] |country = [[England]] |predecessor = Nutrition and Food Research Group<ref name=about/> |parent_organization = [[Oxford Brookes University]] |website = {{URL|https://www.brookes.ac.uk/shssw/nutrition/research/oxbcnh/}} }} The '''Oxford Brookes Centre for Nutrition and Health''' is the first research centre in the [[United Kingdom]] dedicated to researching [[functional food]]s.<ref name="nextgenerationfood.com"/>
==History== The Oxford Brookes Centre for Nutrition and Health opened as the Functional Food Centre at [[Oxford Brookes University]] in early 2009 with a £300,000 grant from the [[Higher Education Funding Council for England]].<ref name=Telegraph>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/foodanddrink/healthyeating/5082444/Debunking-food-myths-the-launch-of-the-Functional-Food-Centre.html|title=Debunking food myths: the launch of the Functional Food Centre|author=Rose Prince|date=1 April 2009|work=Telegraph.co.uk}}</ref><ref name=oxfordtimes/> It was formerly known as the Nutrition and Food Research Group, which had been in existence since 1984.<ref name=about>{{cite web|title=About us|url=http://www.shs.brookes.ac.uk/research/functional-food/about|website=Functional Food Center|publisher=Oxford Brookes University|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref> Its founding director, Jeya Henry, is a consultant to the [[World Health Organization]], [[UNICEF]] and the [[Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations|Food and Agriculture Organisation of the United Nations]] on nutrition assessment, food safety and nutrient requirements.<ref name="nextgenerationfood.com">{{cite news|url=http://www.nextgenerationfood.com/article/The-best-remedy/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714175414/http://www.nextgenerationfood.com/article/The-best-remedy/|archive-date=14 July 2011 |title=The best remedy|first=Stacey |last=Sheppard|newspaper=Next Generation Food|publisher=GDS Publishing |accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Oxford Brookes academic to help set world guidelines on fat consumption |url=https://www.brookes.ac.uk/about-brookes/news/oxford-brookes-academic-to-help-set-world-guidelines-on-fat-consumption/ |location= |publisher=Oxford Brookes University |agency= |date=8 September 2008 |access-date=2015-09-04}}</ref> The centre offers research and consultancy services to the food industry, the United Nations and various Government agencies.<ref name=oxfordtimes>{{cite news|url=http://www.oxfordtimes.co.uk/news/features/4205987.Tackling_diseases_of_affluence/|title=Tackling diseases of affluence|author=Reg Little|newspaper=The Oxford Times|date=18 March 2009|accessdate=4 September 2015}}</ref>
==Areas of research== The Oxford Brookes Centre for Nutrition and Health has the goal of providing scientific information about food and health to consumers, government and the food industry.<ref name=oxfordtimes/> It tests popular claims about food, for example that [[genetically modified crops]] will feed the world, that substances such as [[Omega-3 fatty acid|omega-3]] in [[fish oil]] will make children more intelligent, or that [[antioxidant]]s can reduce cancer by removing [[Radical (chemistry)|free radicals]].<ref name=Telegraph/> It develops new food products such as low [[glycemic index]] bread, which reduces [[cholesterol]] and [[blood sugar]] levels and help weight loss.<ref name=oxfordtimes/> It researches lesser-known foods such as [[breadfruit]], [[cassava]], [[sorghum]] and [[millet]].<ref name=Telegraph/> The health issues that are its research priorities are [[diabetes]], [[obesity]] and the impact of food on age-related problems.<ref name=oxfordtimes/>
==See also== *[[British Dietetic Association]] *[[British Nutrition Foundation]] *[[Food Standards Agency]] *[[Royal Society of Medicine]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.brookes.ac.uk/shssw/nutrition/research/oxbcnh/ Official website]

revision.text:
The '''Patient Reported Outcome Indices for Multiple Sclerosis''' (PRIMUS) is a disease specific [[patient-reported outcome]] [[questionnaire]] which measures the [[quality of life]] (QoL) of patients suffering from [[multiple sclerosis]].<ref name="mckenna">{{cite journal|last=Doward|first=LC|author2=McKenna, S.P. |author3=Meads, D.M. |author4=Twiss, J |author5= Eckert, BJ |title=The development of patient-reported outcome indices for multiple sclerosis (PRIMUS)|journal=Multiple Sclerosis Journal|year=2009|volume=15|issue=9|pages=1092–1102|doi=10.1177/1352458509106513|url=http://msj.sagepub.com/content/15/9/1092.abstract|accessdate=8 October 2013|pmid=19556315}}</ref>
The measure contains an assessment of quality of life, activity limitations and symptoms. A higher score on any or all of these scales indicates a lower quality of life due to the disease.<ref name="twiss">{{cite journal|last=Twiss|first=James|author2=Doward, Lynda C. |author3=McKenna, Stephen P. |author4= Eckert, Benjamin |title=Interpreting scores on multiple sclerosis-specific patient reported outcome measures (the PRIMUS and U-FIS)|journal=Health And Quality Of Life Outcomes|date=11/10/2010|volume=8|issue=117|pages=1–8|doi=10.1186/1477-7525-8-117|url=http://www.hqlo.com/content/8/1/117|accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref>
== History and properties == First published in 2009 by Galen Research and funded by [[Novartis Pharmaceuticals]], the PRIMUS was developed in order to provide a more holistic view of the impact of MS on a patient.<ref name="mckenna" />
The measure has three scales: quality of life, symptoms and activity limitations, which are designed to be used together or as standalone measures.<ref name="twiss" /> The QoL and symptom scales are based on simple statements with [[Dichotomous question|dichotomous]] response options. Each scale has a total score which ranges from 0 to 22. The activity scale is based on 15 statements describing tasks. Patients are asked to rate their ability to perform these tasks on a scale from 1 to 3. The total score of the activities section ranges from 0 to 30.<ref name="2kenna">{{cite journal|last=McKenna|first=Stephen P. |author2=Doward, Lynda C. |author3=Twiss, James |author4=Hagell, Peter |author5=Oprandi, Nadia C. |author6=Fisk, John |author7=Grand'Maison, Francois |author8=Bhan, Virender |author9=Arbizu, Txomin |author10=Brassat, David |author11=Kohlmann, Thomas |author12=Meads, David M. |author13=Eckert, Benjamin J. |title=International Development of the Patient-Reported Outcome Indices for Multiple Sclerosis (PRIMUS)|journal=Value in Health|date=December 2010|volume=13|issue=8|pages=946–951|doi=10.1111/j.1524-4733.2010.00767.x|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1524-4733.2010.00767.x/abstract|accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref>
== International use == Since the development of the PRIMUS, it has been translated into several languages including Canadian English and French, French, German, Italian, Spanish, Swedish, US English,<ref name="2kenna" /> Australian and New Zealand English and US Spanish.<ref>{{cite web|title=Measures Database|url=http://www.galen-research.com/measures-database/|work=Galen-Research.com|publisher=Galen Research|accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> This has allowed researchers to conduct studies for specific populations, such as Spain<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hernandez|first=M.A.|author2=Mora, S.|title=Use of the PRIMUS scale to assess quality of life in a Spanish population of multiple sclerosis patients.|journal=Neurologia|year=2013|volume=28|issue=6|pages=340–347|doi=10.1016/j.nrleng.2012.06.003|url=http://zl.elsevier.es/en/revista/neurologia-495/articulo/use-of-the-primus-scale-90217987|accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref> and Europe.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Karampampa|first=Korinna|author2=Gustavsson, Anders |author3=Miltenburger, Carolin |author4= Eckert, Benjamin |title=Treatment experience, burden and unmet needs (TRIBUNE) in MS study: results from five European countries|journal=Multiple Sclerosis|year=2012|volume=18|issue=2|pages=7–15|doi=10.1177/1352458512441566|url=http://msj.sagepub.com/content/18/2_suppl/7|accessdate=8 October 2013}}</ref>
== Clinical studies == The PRIMUS has been utilized in clinical trials which assess the efficacy of a treatment or medication. If a patient’s score on the PRIMUS changes after a trial has taken place, it is inferred that the trial has had an effect on the patient’s quality of life. PRIMUS has been used to assess the efficacy of [[fingolimod]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Ziemssen|first=T.|author2=Meergans, M. |author3=Vollmar, P. |author4=Kempcke, R |author5=Tracik, F. |author6= van Lokven, T. |title=Study design and first interim results of a registry study to establish long-term safety and pharmaco-economic data on fingolimod (Gilenya®) in multiple sclerosis patients in Germany (PANGAEA)|journal=Multiple Sclerosis|date=October 2012|volume=18|issue=4|page=222|doi=10.1177/1352458512459019|url=http://msj.sagepub.com/content/18/4_suppl/55.extract|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite conference |first = van Lokven |last = T. |author2 = Kempcke, R. |author3 = Ziemssen, T. |author4 = Meergans, M. |title = Study design of a non-interventional registry study to establish long-term safety and pharmaco-economic data on fingolimod (Gilenya®) in multiple sclerosis patients (PANGAEA) |booktitle = 5th Joint triennial congress of the European and Americas Committees for Treatment and Research in Multiple Sclerosis |date = 2011-10-20 |location = Amsterdam, The Netherlands |url = http://registration.akm.ch/einsicht.php?XNABSTRACT_ID=137571&XNSPRACHE_ID=2&XNKONGRESS_ID=150&XNMASKEN_ID=900 |accessdate = 09/10/2013 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://archive.is/20131108154143/http://registration.akm.ch/einsicht.php?XNABSTRACT_ID=137571&XNSPRACHE_ID=2&XNKONGRESS_ID=150&XNMASKEN_ID=900 |archivedate = 2013-11-08 |df = }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Cascione|first=Mark|author2=Wynn, Daniel |author3=Agashivala, Neetu |author4=McCague, Kevin |author5=Pestreich, Linda |author6=Schofield, Lesley |author7=Kim, Edward |author8= Barbato, Luigi |title=Patient-Reported Treatment Satisfaction, Reasons for Therapy Change, and Health-Related Quality of Life at Baseline from the Trial To Evaluate Patient OutComes, Safety and Tolerability of Fingolimod|journal=Neurology|date=12/02/2013|volume=80|issue=1|url=http://www.neurology.org/cgi/content/meeting_abstract/80/1_MeetingAbstracts/P03.222|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref> and multicentre trial on safety and efficacy of rivastigmine in cognitively impaired multiple sclerosis patients|journal=Multiple revision.text:
The '''Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life''' (PsAQoL) measure is a disease specific [[patient-reported outcome]] measure which measures the effect that [[psoriatic arthritis]] has on a patient’s [[quality of life]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Brodszky|first=V |author2=Pentek, M |author3=Balint, PV |author4=Geher, P |author5=Hajdu, O |author6=Hodinka, L |author7=Horvath, G |author8=Koo, E |author9=Polgar, A |author10=Sesztak, M |author11=Szanto, S |author12=Ujfalussy, I |author13=Gulacsi, L|title=Comparison of the Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life (PsAQoL) questionnaire, the functional status (HAQ) and utility (EQ-5D) measures in psoriatic arthritis: results from a cross-sectional survey|journal=Scandinavian Journal of Rheumatology|date=August 2010|volume=39|issue=4|pages=303–309|doi=10.3109/03009740903468982|url=http://informahealthcare.com/doi/abs/10.3109/03009740903468982|accessdate=9 October 2013|pmid=20166848}}</ref>
It is a self-administered, 20-item [[questionnaire]] that takes about three minutes to complete.<ref name="mckenna">{{cite journal|last=McKenna|first=S|author2=Doward, L |author3=Whalley, D |author4=Tennant, A |author5=Emery, P |author6= Veale, D |title=Development of the PsAQoL: a quality of life instrument specific to psoriatic arthritis|journal=Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases|date=February 2004|volume=63|issue=2|pages=162–169|doi=10.1136/ard.2003.006296|pmc=1754880|pmid=14722205}}</ref> The answers are restricted to true or false.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Roussou|first=Euthalia|author2=Chopra, Sunil |author3=Ngandu, Danny Lunda |title=Phenotypic and clinical differences between Caucasian and South Asian patients with psoriatic arthritis living in North East London|journal=Clinical Rheumatology|year=2013|volume=32|pages=591–599|doi=10.1007/s10067-012-2139-5|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10067-012-2139-5|accessdate=9 October 2013|issue=5|pmid=23247553}}</ref>
== Development ==
The PsAQoL was first published in 2004 by Galen Research. The development of the measure was a joint effort between Galen Research, the [[University of Leeds]] and [[St. Vincent’s University Hospital]] in Dublin. The study was funded by the [[Arthritis Research Campaign]] in the UK.<ref name="mckenna" />
[[Qualitative research|Qualitative]] interviews were conducted with 48 patients, after which a 51-item questionnaire was created. A follow up survey with 94 patients was then conducted which reduced the items to 35. An additional 286 patients were surveyed and [[Rasch model|Rasch]] analysis was performed, which finalized the PsAQoL to 20 items.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mease|first=Philip J.|title=Measures of Psoriatic Arthritis|journal=Arthritis Care & Research|date=November 2011|volume=63|issue=S11|pages=S64–S85|doi=10.1002/acr.20577|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/acr.20577/pdf|accessdate=9 October 2013|pmid=22588772}}</ref> A high score on the PsAQoL indicates a lower quality of life.
== International Use ==
The Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life measure has been translated into 30 languages, other than UK English.<ref>{{cite web|title=Measures Database|url=http://www.galen-research.com/measures-database/|work=Galen-Research.com|publisher=Galen Research|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref> These languages include Dutch<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wink|first=Freke|author2=Arends, Suzanne |author3=McKenna, Stephen P. |author4=Houtman, Pieternella M. |author5=Brouwer, Elisabeth |author6= Spoorenberg, Anneke |title=Validity and Reliability of the Dutch Adaptation of the Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life (PsAQoL) Questionnaire|journal=PLoS ONE|year=2013|volume=8|issue=2|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0055912|url=http://www.plosone.org/article/info%3Adoi%2F10.1371%2Fjournal.pone.0055912|accessdate=9 October 2013|editor1-last=Kuwana|editor1-first=Masataka|pages=e55912|pmid=23418474|pmc=3572180}}</ref> and Swedish.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Billing|first=E|author2=McKenna, SP |author3=Staun, M |author4= Lindqvist, U |title=Adaptation of the Psoriatic Arthritis Quality of Life (PsAQoL) instrument for Sweden|journal=Scandinavian Journal of Rheumatology|date=May 2010|volume=39|issue=3|pages=223–228|doi=10.3109/03009740903347975|url=http://informahealthcare.com/doi/abs/10.3109/03009740903347975|accessdate=9 October 2013|pmid=20063984}}</ref> The PsAQoL has also been utilized in [[clinical research]] studies in order to determine whether a medication or treatment is effective in treating psoriatic arthritis. If the scores on the PsAQoL change after treatment, this means that the given treatment has had an effect on quality of life. The PsAQoL has been used to evaluate [[infliximab]]<ref>{{cite journal|last=Marzo-Ortega|first=Helena|author2=McGonagle, Dennis |author3=Rhodes, Laura A |author4=Tan, Ai Lyn |author5=Conaghan, Philip G |author6=O'Connor, Philip |author7=Tanner, Steven F. |author8=Fraser, Alexander |author9=Veale, Douglas |author10= Emery, Paul |title=Efficacy of infliximab on MRI-determined bone oedema in psoriatic arthritis|journal=Annals of the Rheumatic Diseases|year=2007|volume=66|pages=778–781|doi=10.1136/ard.2006.063818|url=http://ard.bmj.com/content/66/6/778.abstract|accessdate=9 October 2013|issue=6|pmid=17185324|pmc=1954680}}</ref> and [[adalimumab]].<ref>{{cite web|title=A Canadian Open-Label Study to Evaluate the Safety and Effectiveness of Adalimumab When Added to Inadequate Therapy for the Treatment of Psoriatic Arthritis (PsA) (ACCLAIM)|url=http://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT00427362?term=PsAQoL&rank=2|work=ClinicalTrials.gov|publisher=Abbott|accessdate=9 October 2013}}</ref>

{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Refeeding syndrome | synonyms = | image = Starved Vietnamese man, 1966.JPEG | caption = | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Refeeding syndrome''' is a [[syndrome]] consisting of metabolic disturbances that occur as a result of reinstitution of nutrition to patients who are [[starvation|starved]], severely [[malnourishment|malnourished]] or metabolically stressed due to severe illness. When too much food and/or liquid nutrition supplement is consumed during the initial four to seven days of refeeding, this triggers synthesis of [[glycogen]], fat and protein in cells, to the detriment of [[serum (blood)|serum (blood)]] concentrations of potassium, magnesium, and phosphorus.<ref name=pmid18583681>{{cite journal |vauthors=Mehanna HM, Moledina J, Travis J |title=Refeeding syndrome: what it is, and how to prevent and treat it |journal=BMJ |volume=336 |issue=7659 |pages=1495–8 |date=June 2008 |pmid=18583681 |pmc=2440847 |doi=10.1136/bmj.a301 |url=http://bmj.com/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18583681}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Doig|first=GS|last2=Simpson|first2=F|last3=Heighes|first3=|last4=Bellomo|first4=R|last5=Chesher|first5=D|last6=Caterson|first6=ID|last7=Reade|first7=MC|last8=Harrigan|first8=PWJ|date=2015-12-01|title=Restricted versus continued standard caloric intake during the management of refeeding syndrome in critically ill adults: a randomised, parallel-group, multicentre, single-blind controlled trial|journal=The Lancet Respiratory Medicine|volume=3|issue=12|pages=943–952|doi=10.1016/S2213-2600(15)00418-X|issn=2213-2619|pmid=26597128}}</ref> Cardiac, pulmonary and neurological symptoms can be signs of refeeding syndrome. The low serum minerals, if severe enough, can be fatal.
==Cause== Any individual who has had negligible nutrient intake for many consecutive days and/or is metabolically stressed from a critical illness or major surgery is at risk of refeeding syndrome. Refeeding syndrome usually occurs within four days of starting to re-feed. Patients can develop fluid and [[electrolyte]] disorders, especially [[hypophosphatemia]], along with neurologic, pulmonary, cardiac, neuromuscular, and hematologic complications.
During [[fasting]] the body switches its main fuel source from carbohydrates to fat tissue [[fatty acids]] and [[amino acids]] as the main energy sources. The spleen decreases its rate of red blood cell breakdown thus conserving [[red blood cell]]s. Many intracellular minerals become severely depleted during this period, although serum levels remain normal. Importantly, [[insulin]] secretion is suppressed in this fasted state and [[glucagon]] secretion is increased.<ref name=pmid18583681/>
During refeeding, insulin secretion resumes in response to increased [[blood sugar]], resulting in increased glycogen, fat and protein synthesis. This process requires [[phosphate]]s, [[magnesium]] and [[potassium]] which are already depleted and the stores rapidly become used up. Formation of phosphorylated carbohydrate compounds in the liver and skeletal muscle depletes intracellular [[Adenosine triphosphate|ATP]] and [[2,3-diphosphoglycerate]] in [[red blood cells]], leading to cellular dysfunction and inadequate oxygen delivery to the body's organs. Refeeding increases the [[basal metabolic rate]]. Intracellular movement of electrolytes occurs along with a fall in the [[blood serum|serum]] electrolytes, including [[phosphorus]] and [[magnesium]]. Levels of serum glucose may rise and the B<sub>1</sub> vitamin [[thiamine]] may fall. [[Arrhythmia|Abnormal heart rhythms]] are the most common cause of death from refeeding syndrome, with other significant risks including confusion, [[coma]] and convulsions and [[cardiac failure]].{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
This syndrome can occur at the beginning of treatment for [[anorexia nervosa]] when patients have an increase in calorie intake and can be fatal.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Webb GJ, Smith K, Thursby-Pelham F, Smith T, Stroud MA, Da Silva AN |title=Complications of emergency refeeding in anorexia nervosa: case series and review |journal=Acute Medicine |volume=10 |issue=2 |pages=69–76 |year=2011 |pmid=22041604 }}</ref> It can also occur after the onset of a severe illness or major surgery. The shifting of electrolytes and fluid balance increases cardiac workload and heart rate. This can lead to acute heart failure. Oxygen consumption is also increased which strains the respiratory system and can make weaning from ventilation more difficult.
==Diagnosis== Refeeding syndrome can be fatal if not recognized and treated properly. An awareness of the condition and a high index of suspicion are required in order to make the diagnosis. The electrolyte disturbances of the refeeding syndrome can occur within the first few days of refeeding. Close monitoring of blood biochemistry is therefore necessary in the early refeeding period.
==Treatment== In critically ill patients admitted to an [[intensive care unit]], if [[phosphate]] drops to below 0.65 mmol/L (2.0 mg/dL) from a previously normal level within three days of starting enteral or parenteral nutrition, caloric intake should be reduced to 480 kcals per day for at least two days whilst electrolytes are replaced. Prescribing [[thiamine]], [[vitamin B]] complex (strong) and a [[multivitamin|multivitamin and mineral preparation]] is recommended. Biochemistry should be monitored regularly until it is stable. Although clinical trials are lacking in patients other than those admitted to an intensive care, it is commonly recommended that [[Energy balance (biology)|energy intake]] should remain lower than that normally required for the first 3–5 days of treatment of refeeding syndrome.
See NICE Clinical guideline CG32, section 6.6.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nutrition support in adults: oral nutrition support, enteral tube feeding and parenteral nutrition. Full guideline [NICE. Clinical guideline CG32]|url=https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/cg32/evidence|website=National Institute for Clinical Excellence|accessdate=April 26, 2017|date=2006–2014}}</ref> On first aid and preliminary medical management, see for example the guidance by [[HMS Monmouth (F235)|HMS Monmouth]] medical officer.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Jeffery SM, Freshwater DA |title=Management of starvation in a Role 1 setting |journal=Journal of the Royal Naval Medical Service |volume=98 |issue=1 |pages=9–15 |year=2012 |pmid=22558735}}</ref> ==History== A common error, repeated in multiple papers, is that "The syndrome was first described after [[World War II]] in Americans who, held by the [[Empire of Japan|Japanese]] as [[prisoners of war#World War II|prisoners of war]], had become malnourished during captivity and who were then released to the care of United States personnel in the [[Philippines]]."<ref name="pmid14847450">{{cite journal|year=1951|title=A clinical study of malnutrition in Japanese prisoners of war|journal=Annals of Internal Medicine|volume=35|issue=1|pages=69–96|doi=10.7326/0003-4819-35-1-69|pmid=14847450|vauthors=Schnitker MA, Mattman PE, Bliss TL|url=https://www.annals.org/article.aspx?volume=35&issue=1&page=69}}</ref> However, closer inspection of the 1951 paper by Schnitker reveals the prisoners under study were not American POWs but Japanese soldiers who, already malnourished, surrendered in the Philippines during 1945, after the war was over.
It is difficult to ascertain when the syndrome was first discovered and named, but it is likely the associated electrolyte disturbances were identified well before 1951, perhaps in Holland during the closing months of World War II, before Victory Day in Europe.<ref>{{cite journal|last2=BSandstead|first2=HR|last3=Drummond|first3=J|date=1945|title=Starvation in Western Holland: 1945.|journal=Lancet|volume=246|pages=282–83.|doi=10.1016/s0140-6736(45)90738-0|last1=Burger|first1=GCE}}</ref> There are also anecdotal eyewitness reports from a still earlier time of Polish prisoners in Iran who were freed from Soviet camps in 1941–1942 under an amnesty to form an army under General Anders and were given food whilst in a state of starvation which caused many to die.<ref>Many of these deaths were due to dysentry, typhoid and other diseases but this was largely amongst the civilian evacuees from Poland. Clear eyewitness reports identify eating too much as a cause.</ref>
The Roman Historian Flavius [[Josephus]] writing in first century the described classic symptoms of the syndrome among survivors of the [[Siege of Jerusalem (70 CE)|siege of Jerusalem]]. He described the death of those who over indulged in food after famine, whereas those who ate a more restrained pace survived.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.gutenberg.org/files/2850/2850-h/2850-h.htm#link52HCH0013|title=The Wars of the Jews by Flavius Josephus|last=|first=|date=|website=www.gutenberg.org|page=book V, chapter XIII, paragraph 4|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-05-22}}</ref>
In his 5th century BCE work 'On Fleshes' (De Carnibus), [[Hippocrates]] writes, "if a person goes seven days without eating or drinking anything, in this period most die; but there are some who survive that time but still die, and others are persuaded not to starve themselves to death but to eat and drink: however, the cavity no longer admits anything because the jejunum (nêstis) has grown together in that many days, and these people too die." Though [[Hippocrates]] misidentifies the exact cause of death, this passage likely represents an early description of Refeeding Syndrome.<ref>Hippocrates of Kos. De Carnibus. 5th century BCE.</ref>

'''Social quality''' is a way of understanding society which is also relevant for social and public policy. Social quality looks at elements that should constitute a good or decent society. It contributes to the body of work concerned with understanding social progress going beyond [[Gross domestic product|GDP]], taking into account the work of the [[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development]] and the [[European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions]]. Whilst most approaches have concentrated on the [[happiness economics|economics]] or [[Subjective well-being|psychology of well-being]], social quality can help understanding the social conditions that enable human flourishing.<ref name="social quality">{{cite journal |last=Abbott |first=Pamela |last2=Wallace |first2=Claire |date=2012 |title=Social Quality: A way to measure the quality of society |journal=Social Indicators Research |volume=108 |issue=1 |pages=153–167 |doi=10.1007/s11205-011-9871-0 |pmid=22773884 |pmc=3384781}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:Social quality.png|400px|right|Social quality diagram]]
There are four elements shown in the diagram on the right. ''Economic security'' refers to the material conditions that enable people to have a long term perspective on their lives, and their confidence for the future. This can include social policies, such as pensions and social security, that ensure this. It also includes economic conditions that enable people to feel secure because they have enough income to cover their basic needs.<ref name="social quality" /> ''Social cohesion'' refers to the bonds that link societies together, deriving from the work of [[Émile Durkheim]].<ref>{{cite book |last=Durkheim |first=Émile |date=1952 |title=Suicide. A Study in Sociology |location=London |publisher=Routledge }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Durkheim |first=Émile |date=1952 |title=The Division of Labour in Society|location=New York |publisher=Free Press }}</ref> [[Émile Durkheim]]'s work considers the moral and social relationships between members of society and social groups, including factors such as trust in others, trust in social institutions, a sense of identity, a collective consciousness, solidarity and commitment to the common good of society.<ref>{{cite book |last=Dragolov |first=Georgi |last2=Ignácz |first2=Zsófia |last3=Lorenz |first3=Jan |last4=Delhey |first4=Jan| last5=Boehnke |first5=Klaus |date=2013 |title=Social Cohesion Radar. Measuring Common Ground. An international Comparison of Social Cohesion|location=Gutersloh |publisher=Bertelsmann }}</ref> ''Social inclusion'' refers to the way in which individuals and social groups are included into society, either through employment, networks and family or through access to social support of various kinds, this can come through support from other people or from social policies. Social policies that foster social inclusion, reduce poverty and tackle other forms of social exclusion can be important in this respect.<ref name="social quality" /> ''Social empowerment'' refers to the conditions that enable people to participate in their society, such as having good health, education and democratic opportunities for participation, such as voting and joining civil society. However, it can also mean the feelings of being empowered, being able to take control of one's circumstances. It derives from the work of [[Amartya Sen]], who suggests that people need to have the capability to be able to do the things that they wish to do.<ref>{{cite book |last=Sen |first=Amartya |editor-last=Nussbaum |editor-first=Martha Craven |editor-last2=Sen |editor-first2=Amartya|title=The Quality of Life |location=London|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan |date=1993 |chapter=Capability and Well-being }}</ref>
However, the social quality approach is fundamentally relational. As such, it emphasises a complex field of conditional (i), constitutional (ii) and normative factors (iii). These are (i) Socio-Economic Security, Social Cohesion, Social Inclusion, Social Empowerment; (ii) Person/human security, Social Recognition, Social Responsiveness, Personal/human Capacity; and (iii) Social Justice (Equity), Solidarity, Equal Valuation, Human Dignity. On the one hand this rejects the Durkheimian view on society as an independent social fact sui generis; on the other hand it qualifies Sen's approach as social quality is not primarily focusing on the subjective side and individuals within society but on the constitution of society by way of people producing and reproducing their daily life and with this society.
==Origins and development== The idea of social quality began as a [[European Union]] project among a group of social scientists, concerned to develop a better way forward for social policies in Europe.<ref>{{cite book |last=Beck |first=Wolfang |last2=van der Maesen |first2=Laurent |last3=Walker |first3=Alan |date=1997 |title=The Social Quality of Europe|location=The Hague |publisher=Kluwer Law International}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Beck |first=Wolfang |last2=van der Maesen |first2=Laurent |last3=Walker |first3=Alan |last4=Thomes |first4=Fleur |date=2001 |title=Social Quality: A Vision for Europe|location=The Hague |publisher=Kluwer Law International }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |editor-last=van der Maesen |editor-first=Laurent |editor-last2=Walker |editor-first2=Alan |date=2012 |title=Social Quality. From Theory to Indicators|location=London |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan }}</ref> Later the concept underwent some fundamental development. Empirically it had been developed amongst others by Pamela Abbott, [[Claire Wallace]] and Roger Sapsford, who looked at how the model can be developed empirically in Europe, [[Eastern Europe]], [[Central Asia]], China and [[Rwanda]]. They have used a different variation, considering the impact on well being, measured through [[life satisfaction]] and human flourishing in order to understand how social quality might work in fostering the well being of people in society.<ref name="social quality" /><ref>{{cite book |last=Abbott |first=Pamela| last2=Wallace| first2=Claire |editor-last=Selin|editor-first=Helaine |editor-last2=Gareth|editor-first2=Gaveth|title=Happiness across Cultures: Views of Happiness and Quality of Life in Non-Western Cultures |location=London|publisher=Springer Verlag|date=2012 |chapter=Happiness in Post-Conflict Rwanda| pages= 361–376}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Abbott |first=Pamela| last2=Wallace| first2=Claire |editor-last=Selin|editor-first=Helaine |editor-last2=Gareth|editor-first2=Gaveth|title=Happiness across Cultures: Views of Happiness and Quality of Life in Non-Western Cultures |location=London|publisher=Springer Verlag|date=2012 |chapter=Satisfaction and Societal Quality in Kazakhstan| pages= 107–120}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Abbott |first=Pamela |last2=Wallace |first2=Claire |date=2014 |title='Rising economic prosperity and social quality. The case of new member states of the European Union |url= https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs11205-012-9992-0|journal=Social Indicators Research |volume=115 |issue=1 |pages=419–439 |doi=10.1007/s11205-012-9992-0 |accessdate=5 January 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Abbott |first=Pamela |last2=Wallace |first2=Claire|last3=Sapsford |first3=Roger |date=2010|title='Surviving the transformation: Social quality in Central Asia and the Caucasus |url= https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10902-010-9187-9|journal=Journal of Happiness Studies |volume=12 |issue=2 |pages=199–223 |doi=10.1007/s10902-010-9187-9 |accessdate=5 January 2015}}</ref> This empirical work had been to a large extent emerging from the work undertaken by colleagues in Asia, in particular by Ka Lin.<ref>{{cite book|last=Lin |first=Ka |last2=Herrmann |first2=Peter |date=2015 |title=Social Quality Theory. A New Perspective on Social Development|location=New York/Oxford |publisher=Berghahn}}</ref> Another development is by a marked shift towards questions around 'overall sustainability'. Laurent van der Maesen is the main proponent of this strand contends. In a working paper we read that "international and national (and urban) strategies and policies for development toward 'overall' sustainability not only have to have a strong emphasis on development toward sustainability of cities themselves (internal sustainability) but also – simultaneously – address the development toward sustainability of the cities' surroundings ('Hinterland')".<ref>{{cite journal |last=International Association of Social Quality |date=2012 |title=The need for a Comprehensive Conceptual and Methodological Framework for new politics and policies: A social quality perspective; A contribution to the Rio+ 20 Conference on the sustainability of human existence on Earth |journal=IASQ working papers |issue=11 |pages=12 f.1}}</ref>
A more traditional line is maintained by [[Peter Herrmann (social philosopher)|Peter Herrmann]] who had been since the end of the 1990s advisor of the then European Foundation, later International Association of Social Quality. He claims that "[w]e have to reconceptualize ... indicators. They are not measurement instruments sui generis. Rather they are instruments to develop an understanding of complex issues and trends. As such they need to be guided by a sound conceptual reflection of what they are looking for".<ref>{{cite journal |last=Herrmann |first=Peter |date=2012 |title=Economic Performance, Social Progress and Social Quality |journal=International Journal of Social Quality |volume=2 |issue=1 |pages=41–55 |doi=10.3167/IJSQ.2012.020104 }}</ref> Herrmann is on the one hand reclaiming the methodological and theoretical importance of Social Quality thinking, at least qualifying the empirical orientation. On the other hand, though this does not contradict the orientation on sustainability, Herrmann emphasises the need to reorient debates on "the kind of economy in place" instead of maintaining dichotomies, separations and hierarchies between different areas of societal development. This had been elaborated in a book on defining social policy as matter of producing society.<ref>{{cite book |last=Herrmann |first=Peter |date=2014 |title=Social Policy – Production rather than Distribution. A Rights-Based Approach|location=Bremen |publisher=EHV}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Eudaimonia]] – Greek word used as a translation for "human flourishing"
==Notes== <references />
==References== *{{cite news |last=Wallace |first=Claire |date=5 November 2014 |title=Beyond GDP: happiness is about more than just individuals |url=http://theconversation.com/beyond-gdp-happiness-is-about-more-than-just-individuals-33768 |newspaper=[[The Conversation (website)|The Conversation]] |accessdate= 5 January 2015}}

{{Network Science}}
'''Targeted immunization strategies''' are approaches designed to increase the [[immunization]] level of populations and decrease the chances of [[epidemic]] [[outbreaks]].<ref name=PastorVespignani2002> {{cite journal |last1=Pastor-Satorras |first1=Romualdo |last2=Vespignani |first2=Alessandro |title=Immunization of complex networks |journal=Physical Review E |date=February 8, 2002 |volume=65 |issue=36104 |pages=036104 |pmid=11909162 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.65.036104 |arxiv=cond-mat/0107066 |bibcode=2002PhRvE..65c6104P }} </ref><ref name=CohenHavlinAvraham2003> {{cite journal |last1=Cohen |first1=Reuven |last2=Havlin |first2=Shlomo |last3=ben-Avraham |first3=Daniel |title=Efficient immunization strategies for computer networks and populations |journal=Physical Review Letters |date=December 9, 2003 |volume=91 |issue=24 |page=247901 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.91.247901 |bibcode=2003PhRvL..91x7901C |pmid=14683159 |arxiv=cond-mat/0207387 }} </ref> Though often in regards to use in healthcare practices and the administration of vaccines to prevent biological epidemic outbreaks,<ref name=CDCvaccinesandimmunization> {{cite web |title=Vaccines and immunization |url=https://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/vpd-vac/fact-sheet-parents.html |website=www.cdc.gov/vaccines/ |publisher=Center for Disease Control and Prevention |accessdate=17 November 2014}} </ref> these strategies refer in general to immunization schemes in [[complex networks]], biological, social or artificial in nature.<ref name=PastorVespignani2002 /> Identification of at-risk groups and individuals with higher odds of spreading the disease often plays an important role in these strategies.<ref name=PastorVespignani2002 /><ref name=CohenHavlinAvraham2003 /><ref name=VNAnurses> {{cite news |last1=Piddle |first1=Samanta |title=VNA nurses bring shots to school |url=http://www.clintonherald.com/news/article_f0c059b6-3747-507f-80bc-d705f71357d9.html |accessdate=15 November 2014 |publisher=Clinton Herald |date=October 14, 2014}} </ref>
==Background==
The success of [[vaccines]] and [[anti-virus software]] in preventing major outbreaks relies on the mechanism of [[herd immunity]], also known as community immunity, where the immunization of individuals provides protection for not only the individuals, but also the community at large.<ref name=JohnJacob2000> {{cite journal |last1=John |first1=T. Jacob |last2=Samuel |first2=Reuben |title=Herd immunity and herd effect: new insights and definitions |journal=European Journal of Epidemiology |date=2000-07-01 |volume=16 |issue=7 |pages=601–606 |doi=10.1023/A:1007626510002 |pmid=11078115 }} </ref> In cases of biological contagions such as [[influenza]], [[measles]], and [[chicken pox]], immunizing a [[critical community size]] can provide protection against the disease for members who cannot be vaccinated themselves (infants, pregnant women, and [[immunocompromised]] individuals). Often however these vaccine programmes require the immunization of a large majority of the population to provide herd immunity.<ref name=communityimmunity> {{cite web |url=http://www.niaid.nih.gov/topics/pages/communityimmunity.aspx |title=Community Immunity ("Herd" Immunity) |publisher=National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases |accessdate=7 April 2014}} </ref> A few successful vaccine programmes have led to the [[eradication of infectious diseases]] like [[small pox]]<ref name=HBazinsmallpoxeradication> {{cite book |last1=Bazin |first1=Herve |title=The Eradication of Small Pox |date=2000 |publisher=Academic Press |location=London |isbn=978-0-12-083475-4 }} </ref> and [[rinderpest]], and the near eradication of [[polio]],<ref name=CDCpolioupdate> {{cite web |title=Updates on CDC's Polio Eradication Efforts |url=https://www.cdc.gov/polio/updates/ |website=www.cdc.gov/polio |publisher=Center for Disease Control and Prevention |accessdate=17 November 2014}} </ref> which plagued the world before the second half of the 20th century.<ref name=livesciencepolio> {{cite news |last1=Lewis |first1=Tanya |title=Polio Vaccine: How the US' Most Feared Disease Was Eradicated |url=http://www.livescience.com/48504-polio-vaccine-legacy.html |accessdate=15 November 2014 |agency=Purch |publisher=LiveScience |date=October 28, 2014}} </ref><ref name=poliocomebackNYT> {{cite news |last1=McNeil Jr. |first1=Donald G. |title=Polio’s Return After Near Eradication Prompts a Global Health Warning |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/06/health/world-health-organization-polio-health-emergency.html |accessdate=18 November 2014 |publisher=The New York Times |date=May 5, 2014}} </ref>
==Network-based strategies==
More recently researchers have looked at exploiting network connectivity properties to better understand and design immunization strategies to prevent major epidemic outbreaks.<ref name=CampbellSalathe2013> {{cite journal |last1=Campbell |first1=Ellsworth |last2=Salathe |first2=Marcel |title=Complex social contagion makes networks more vulnerable to disease outbreaks |journal=Scientific Reports |date=May 28, 2013 |volume=3 |pages=1905 |doi=10.1038/srep01905 |pmid=23712758 |pmc=3664906 |bibcode=2013NatSR...3E1905C |arxiv=1211.0518 }} </ref><ref name=GallosLiljeros2007> {{cite journal |last1=Gallos |first1=Lazaros K. |last2=Liljeros |first2=Fredrik |last3=Argyrakis |first3=Panos |last4=Bunde |first4=Armin |last5=Havlin |first5=Shlomo |title=Improving Immunization Strategies |journal=Physical Review E |date=April 19, 2007 |volume=75 |issue=4 |pages=045104 |doi=10.1103/PhysRevE.75.045104 |bibcode=2007PhRvE..75d5104G |arxiv=0704.1589 }} </ref> Many real networks like the [[Internet]], [[world wide web]], and even sexual contact networks<ref name=Liljerossexualcontacts2001> {{cite journal |last1=Liljeros |first1=Fredrik |last2=Edling |first2=Christofer R. |last3=Amaral |first3=Luis A. Nunes |last4=Stanley |first4=Eugene |last5=Aberg |first5=Yvonne |title=The web of human sexual contacts|journal=Nature |date=June 21, 2001 |volume=411 |issue=6840 |pages=907–908 |doi=10.1038/35082140 |pmid=11418846 |bibcode=2001Natur.411..907L |arxiv=cond-mat/0106507 }} </ref> have been shown to be [[scale-free networks]] and as such exhibit a [[power-law]] distribution for the [[degree distribution]]. In large networks this results in the vast majority of nodes (individuals in [[social networks]]) having few connections or low degree ''k'', while a few "hubs" have many more connections than the average <''k''>.<ref name=BAmodel1999> {{cite journal |last1=Barabasi |first1=Albert-Laszlo |last2=Albert |first2=Reka |title=Emergence of scaling in random networks |journal=Science|date=October 15, 1999 |volume=286 |issue=5439 |pages=509–512 |doi=10.1126/science.286.5439.509 |pmid=10521342 |bibcode=1999Sci...286..509B |arxiv=cond-mat/9910332 }} </ref> This wide variability ([[heterogeneity]]) in degree offers immunization strategies based on targeting members of the network according to their connectivity rather than random immunization of the network. In epidemic modeling on scale-free networks, targeted immunization schemes can considerably lower the vulnerability of a network to epidemic outbreaks over random immunization schemes. Typically these strategies result in the need for far fewer nodes to be immunized in order to provide the same level of protection to the entire network as in random immunization.<ref name=PastorVespignani2002 /><ref name=CohenHavlinAvraham2003 /><ref name=Tanaka2014> {{cite journal |last1=Tanaka |first1=Gouhei |last2=Urabe |first2=Chiyori |last3=Aihara |first3=Kazuyuki |title=Random and Targeted Interventions for Epidemic Control in Metapopulation Models |journal=Scientific Reports |date=July 16, 2014 |volume=4 |issue=5522 |pages=5522 |doi=10.1038/srep05522 |bibcode=2014NatSR...4E5522T |pmid=25026972 |pmc=4099978 }} </ref> In circumstances then where vaccines are scarce, efficient immunization strategies become necessary to preventing infectious outbreaks.<ref name=targetedinfluenzavaccines> {{cite journal |last1=Glassner |first1=Daniel |last2=Taneri |first2=Denis |last3=Feng |first3=Zhilan |last4=Chuang |first4=Jen-Hsiang |last5=Tull |first5=Peet |last6=Thompson |first6=William |last7=McCauley |first7=Mary Mason |last8=Alexander |first8=James |title=Evaluation of Targeted Influenza Vaccination Strategies via Population Modeling |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=5 |issue=9 |pages=e12777 |date=September 17, 2010 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0012777 |pmid=20862297 |bibcode=2010PLoSO...512777G |pmc=2941445 }} </ref>
'''Examples'''
A common approach for targeted immunization studies in scale-free networks focuses on targeting the highest degree nodes for immunization. These nodes are the most highly connected in the network, making them more likely to spread the contagion if infected. Immunizing this segment of the network can drastically reduce the impact of the disease on the network and requires the immunization of far fewer nodes compared to randomly selecting nodes.<ref name=PastorVespignani2002 /> However, this strategy relies on knowing the global structure of the network, which may not always be practical.<ref name=CohenHavlinAvraham2003 />
Another strategy, ''acquaintance immunization'',<ref name=CohenHavlinAvraham2003 /><ref name=CohenMadar2004> {{cite journal |last1=Madar |first1=N. |last2=Kalinsky |first2=T. |last3=Cohen |first3=R. |last4=ben-Avraham |first4=D. |last5=Havlin |first5=S. |title=Immunization and epidemic dynamics in complex networks |journal=The European Physical Journal B |date=May 14, 2004 |volume=38 |issue=2 |pages=269–276 |doi=10.1140/epjb/e2004-00119-8 |bibcode=2004EPJB...38..269M }} </ref> tries to target all of the most highly connected nodes for immunization by going through their neighbors without knowing the full [[network topology]]. In this approach a random group of nodes are chosen and then a random set of their neighbors are selected for immunization. The most highly connected nodes are far more likely to be in this group of neighbors so immunizing this group results in targeting the most highly connected but requiring far less information about the network.<ref name=CohenHavlinAvraham2003 /><ref name=ChristakisFowler2010> {{cite journal |last1=Christakis |first1=Nicholas A. |last2=Fowler |first2=James H. |title=Social Network Sensors for Early Detection of Contagious Outbreaks |journal=PLoS ONE |volume=5 |issue=9 |pages=e12948 |date=September 15, 2010 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0012948 |pmid=20856792 |bibcode=2010PLoSO...512948C |pmc=2939797 |arxiv=1004.4792 }} </ref><ref name=KriegerVaccinateThyNeighbor> {{cite news |last1=Krieger |first1=Kim |title=Vaccinate Thy Neighbor |url=http://physics.aps.org/story/v12/st23 |accessdate=18 November 2014 |agency=Physical Review Focus |issue=12 |publisher=American Physical Society}} </ref> Another variant of this strategy again calls for the random selection of nodes but instead asks for one of their neighbors with a higher degree, or at least more than a given threshold degree and immunizes them.<ref name=GallosLiljeros2007 /> These degree based strategies consistently require fewer nodes to be immunized and as such improve a network's chances against epidemic attacks.<ref name=CohenHavlinAvraham2003 /><ref name=CohenMadar2004 />
A recent centrality measure, Percolation Centrality, introduced by Piraveenan et al.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Piraveenan|first=Mahendra|last2=Prokopenko|first2=Mikhail|last3=Hossain|first3=Liaquat|date=2013-01-22|title=Percolation Centrality: Quantifying Graph-Theoretic Impact of Nodes during Percolation in Networks|url=http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0053095|journal=PLOS ONE|volume=8|issue=1|pages=e53095|doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0053095|issn=1932-6203|pmc=3551907|pmid=23349699|bibcode=2013PLoSO...853095P}}</ref> is particularly useful in identifying nodes for vaccination based on the network topology. Unlike node degree which depends on topology alone, however, percolation centrality takes into account the topological importance of a node as well as its distance from infected nodes in deciding its overall importance. Piraveenan et al.<ref name=":0" /> has shown that percolation centrality-based vaccination is particularly effective when the proportion of people already infected is on the same order of magnitude as the number of people who could be vaccinated before the disease spreads much further. If infection spread is at its infancy, then ring-vaccination surrounding the source of infection is most effective, whereas if the proportion of people already infected is much higher than the number of people that could be vaccinated quickly, then vaccination will only help those who are vaccinated and herd immunity cannot be achieved.<ref name="communityimmunity" /> Percolation centrality-based vaccination is most effective in the critical scenario where the infection has already spread too far to be completely surrounded by ring-vaccination, yet not spread wide enough so that it cannot be contained by strategic vaccination. Nevertheless, Percolation Centrality also needs full network topology to be computed, and thus is more useful in higher levels of abstraction (for example, networks of townships rather than social networks of individuals), where the corresponding network topology can more readily be obtained.
==Increasing immunization coverage== Millions of children worldwide do not receive all of the routine vaccinations as per their national schedule. As immunization is a powerful public health strategy for improving child survival, it is important to determine what strategies work best to increase coverage. A Cochrane review assessed the effectiveness of intervention strategies to boost and sustain high childhood immunization coverage in low- and middle income countries.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Oyo-Ita|first1=A|last2=Nwachukwu|first2=CE|last3=Oringanje|first3=C|last4=Meremikwu|first4=MM|title=Interventions for improving coverage of child immunization in low- and middle-income countries.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=6 July 2011|issue=7|pages=CD008145|pmid=21735423|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD008145.pub2}}</ref>{{Update inline|reason=Updated version https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/27394698|date = July 2018}} Fourteen trials were included but most of the evidence was of low quality. Providing parents and other community members with information on immunization, health education at facilities in combination with redesigned immunization reminder cards, regular immunization outreach with and without household incentives, home visits, and integration of immunization with other services may improve childhood immunization coverage in low-and middle income countries.
==See also== * [[Influenza vaccine]] * [[Immunization]] * [[Vaccine-preventable diseases]] * [[smallpox eradication]] * [[Poliomyelitis eradication]] * [[Infectious diseases]] * [[ILOVEYOU]] (computer worm epidemic in 2000) * [[Epidemiology]] * [[Epidemic model]] * [[Network Science]] * [[Critical community size]] * [[Scale-free network]] * [[Complex network]]

'''Testicular rupture''' is a rip or tear in the [[Tunica albuginea of testis|tunica albuginea]] resulting in extrusion of the [[testicle|testicular]] contents, including the [[seminiferous tubule]]s. It is a rare complication of [[testicular trauma]], and can result from blunt or penetrating trauma, though blunt trauma is more likely to cause rupture. Testicular rupture typically results from trauma sustained during a motor vehicle crash or sports play, mainly affects those from the ages of 10-30. The main symptoms of testicular rupture are scrotal swelling and severe pain, which can make diagnosis difficult. Testicular rupture should be suspected whenever blunt trauma to the scrotum has been sustained. Treatment consists of [[Exploratory surgery|surgical exploration]] with repair of the injury.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Advances in diagnosis and management of genital injuries|journal = The Urologic Clinics of North America|date = Aug 2013|issn = 1558-318X|pmid = 23905941|pages = 427–438|volume = 40|issue = 3|doi = 10.1016/j.ucl.2013.04.013|first = Andrew J.|last = Chang|first2 = Steven B.|last2 = Brandes}}</ref>
== Treatment == A potential testicular rupture should be evaluated with [[ultrasound]] imaging.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Male genital trauma in sports|journal = Clinics in Sports Medicine|date = Apr 2013|issn = 1556-228X|pmid = 23522506|pages = 247–254|volume = 32|issue = 2|doi = 10.1016/j.csm.2012.12.012|first = Stanley R.|last = Hunter|first2 = Timothy S.|last2 = Lishnak|first3 = Andria M.|last3 = Powers|first4 = David K.|last4 = Lisle}}</ref> Testicular rupture is treated with surgery, though the procedure performed depends on the magnitude of the injury and the salvageability of the tissue. An [[orchiectomy]] - removal of the affected testis - is done when the testis is not salvageable<ref name=Stein2015>{{cite journal|vauthors=Stein DM, Santucci RA |title=An update on urotrauma|journal=Current Opinion in Urology|volume=25|issue=4|pages=323–30|date=July 2015|pmid=26049876|doi=10.1097/MOU.0000000000000184}}</ref> and leads to reduced [[semen]] quality and higher rates of endocrine dysfunction than repair of salvageable tissue.<ref name=":0" />
== Prognosis == 90% of ruptured testes are successfully repaired when treated surgically within 72 hours; the percentage of successful treatment drops to 45% after this period. Though not typically fatal, testicular rupture can cause [[hypogonadism]], low [[self-esteem]], and [[infertility]].<ref name=":0" />

{{multiple issues| {{BLP sources|date=April 2017}} {{primary sources|date=April 2017}} {{third-party|date=April 2017}} {{unreliable sources|date=April 2017}} }} {{COI|date=February 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Tony Mills | image = Tony Mills M.D..jpg | imagesize = 240px | caption = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|mf=yes|1961|10|12}} | birth_place = [[Columbia, South Carolina]] | death_date = | death_place = | Height = | alma_mater = [[Duke University]]
[[Duke University School of Medicine]] | occupation = [[Physician]] | spouse = Sandro Antunes (July 2014) | children = }} '''Tony Mills''', is an American [[physician]] who specializes in treatment of [[HIV]] and [[AIDS]].[http://www.poz.com/articles/hiv_croi_mills_761_16580.shtml POZ Magazine] He is one of the leading clinician in the fields of Men's Health and HIV disease. Mills has served as the primary care provider for over 2,000 patients, including approximately half living with HIV. Mills received both his undergraduate and medical degrees from Duke University. He completed an internship in Internal Medicine, a residency in Anesthesiology and a fellowship in Cardiovascular Anesthesiology, all at the [[University of California, San Francisco]]. Mills is a member of many professional societies including; the [[Infectious Disease Society of America]], [[International AIDS Society]], IAS-USA, and the American Academy of HIV Medicine. He is the executive director of SoCal Men's Medical Group, the clinical research director of Mills Clinical Research, and the president of the Men's Health Foundation. In May 1998, he won the title of [[International Mister Leather]], publicly coming out as HIV-positive one day later.[http://www.poz.com/articles/220_12063.shtml Andrew Sullivan: Dr. Leather Meets Mr. Right] ==Education== *1981 - B.A., [[Duke University]]; Durham, North Carolina *1984 - Fellowship, Cardiovascular Research Institute; [[University of California, San Francisco]] *1986 - M.D., [[Duke University School of Medicine]]; Durham, North Carolina *1987 - Internship in Internal Medicine; [[University of California, San Francisco]] *1989 - Residency in Anesthesiology; [[University of California, San Francisco]] *1990 - Fellowship in Cardiovascular Anesthesiology; [[University of California, San Francisco]] Mills graduated from [[Duke University School of Medicine]] and was awarded both the Stanley Sarnoff Fellowship Award in Cardiovascular Research and the Eugene Stead Research Award. He began his clinical practice in 1991 at [[Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center]] in [[New York City]], concentrating on [[Organ transplant|heart transplantation]] and [[cardiovascular]] research. In 1994, Mills was named Chief of Pediatric Cardiac Anesthesiology at the [[University of Miami]],[http://www.tagarm.com/dr_mills.html TagArm]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }} where he was actively involved in both the [[Twelve-step program|recovery]] community and in the [[gay community]] as an advocate for people living with HIV. In 1999, he moved to Los Angeles and opened a general medical practice specializing in HIV care. He was certified as an HIV specialist by the American Academy of HIV Medicine in 2000 and currently serves on both the California Board and the National Board of the AAHIVM. In 2002, Mills joined the Clinical Medicine Faculty at [[University of California, Los Angeles|UCLA]] where he works actively with residents and fellows and is a frequent lecturer. He is the current editor of ''HIV Treatment News'' and is a frequent contributor to other HIV-related publications. ==International Mister Leather== On May 5, 1998, having earned the regional title of Mister Mid-Atlantic Leather, Mills entered and won the [[International Mister Leather]] contest, competing against 61 contestants from 7 countries. Since winning the contest, Mills has been featured in the documentaries ''Beyond Vanilla'' and ''Mr. Leather''.[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0271395/ The Internet Movie Database][http://www.mrleather-themovie.com/cast.htm ''Mr. Leather'' official website] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070119082752/http://www.mrleather-themovie.com/cast.htm |date=2007-01-19 }} He has also been a model for the [[COLT Studio Group]]. ==References== {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Mills, Tony}} [[Category:American anesthesiologists]] [[Category:People with HIV/AIDS]] [[Category:Duke University alumni]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Duke University School of Medicine alumni]] [[Category:American primary care physicians]] [[Category:Men's health]]

'''Uni Research Health''' is a department in [[Uni Research]], one of the largest research companies in Norway.Bergens Tidende, 20.11.2009, Part 2, p. 3: Forskning under nytt navn Research Director of Uni Research Health is Professor [[Hege R. Eriksen]].[http://www.bt.no/nyheter/Sliten,-troett,-ryggsmerter,-hodepine-..-933318.html Bergens Tidende 19.09.2009: Sliten, trøtt, ryggsmerter, hodepine ..?] Uni research health has approximately 125 employees, most of them located in Bergen, Norway. == Research units == The research and educational activities of Uni Health are concentrated in the following research units: Centre for Child and Adolescent Mental Health Research

{{long lead|date=May 2018}}
'''Wound assessment''' is a component of [[wound care|wound management]] that collects information about the patient, and the [[wound]] before a treatment plan is prescribed.
Wound assessment includes observation of the wound, surveying the patient, as well as identifying relevant clinical data from physical examination and patient’s health history. Clinical data recorded during an initial assessment serves as a baseline for prescribing the appropriate treatment.
To assist clinicians in standardizing the wound assessment and [[wound bed preparation|preparation of wound bed]] for treatment, the TIME framework has been developed in 2002 by a group of wound care experts.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Schultz|first=GS|last2=Sibbald|first2=RG |last3=Falanga|first3=V|last4=Ayello|first4=EA|last5=Dowsett|first5=C|last6=Harding|first6=K|last7=Romanelli|first7=M|last8=Stacey|first8=MC|last9=Teot|first9=L|last10=Vanscheidt|first10=W |date=March 2003 |title= Wound bed preparation: a systematic approach to wound management |url= http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1046/j.1524-475X.11.s2.1.x/abstract |journal= Wound Repair and Regeneration |volume=11 |issue= s1|pmid=12654015 |doi= 10.1046/j.1524-475X.11.s2.1.x }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Fletcher |first=J |date=April–May 2007 |title= Wound assessment and the TIME framework|journal=British Journal of Nursing |volume=16 |issue=8|pmid= 17551428 |doi= 10.12968/bjon.2007.16.8.23415 }}</ref> The TIME acronym stands for Tissue, Infection/Inflammation, Moisture, and Edge – components that, per the TIME recommendation, should be thoroughly assessed to optimize the treatment. Depending on the clinical findings for each component, TIME recommends certain clinical actions aimed at correcting the issues and facilitating the [[wound healing|healing]].
A recent global anthropological study has prompted clinicians to review the TIME framework<ref name="TWA">{{cite journal | last=Dowsett |first=C | last2=Gronemann | first2=M | last3=Harding | first3=K| date=2015 | title=Taking wound assessment beyond the edge | journal=Wounds International | volume=6 | issue=1 | url=http://www.wintjournal.com/journal-content/view/taking-wound-assessment-beyond-the-edge}}</ref> and resulted in a 2016 development of a new comprehensive tool for wound assessment – the Triangle of Wound Assessment (TWA).<ref>{{cite journal | last=Dowsett |first=C | last2=Protz | first2=K | last3= Drouard | first3=M| last4=Harding | first4=K| date=May 2015 | title= Triangle of wound assessment made easy | journal=Wounds International | url= http://www.woundsinternational.com/media/other-resources/_/1189/files/twa-made-easy_web1.pdf }}</ref> Based on the study’s findings, TWA identifies three zones (wound bed, wound edge, and [[periwound]] skin) that must be included in wound assessment to arrive at clinical decisions that will help heal the wound in the most efficient way. TIME framework components are integrated into the assessment of each zone.
The introduction of periwound skin as a component of wound assessment identifies a significant departure from traditional methods; it emphasizes the importance of addressing periwound skin during treatment in the same measure as wound bed and wound edge.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.worldwidewounds.com/2009/October/Lawton-Langoen/vulnerable-skin-2-utf8.html |title= Assessing and managing vulnerable periwound skin |last=Lawton |first=S |last2= Langøen |first2=A |date=October 2009 |website= World Wide Wounds |publisher=SMTL |access-date= May 9, 2017}}</ref>
Wound assessment is a holistic process that considers the patient’s current state of health, the factors that may impede wound healing, and the cause, duration and state of the wound.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Cornforth |first=A |date=December 2013 |title= Holistic wound assessment in primary care |journal=British Journal of Community Nursing |volume=18 |issue=12|pmid=24796082 }}</ref> As such, this process is applicable to any wound.
==Wound assessment components== ===Health history=== Patient’s health history may include disorders that affect the body’s ability to heal itself. These disorders are called [[comorbidity|comorbidities]] and may interfere with circulatory and metabolic body functions, levels of various physiological assessment components (sugar, albumin, etc.), and induce other factors that negatively affect the healing.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Ackermann |first=PW|last2=Hart |first2=DA |date=October 2013 |title= Influence of Comorbidities: Neuropathy, Vasculopathy, and Diabetes on Healing Response Quality |journal= Advances in Wound Care |volume=2|issue=8 |pmid=24688829|doi=10.1089/wound.2012.0437 |pmc=3842870}}</ref> Common co-morbidities are: [[Diabetes mellitus|diabetes]], [[Chronic venous insufficiency|venous insufficiency]] or [[Peripheral artery disease|peripheral arterial disease]], [[Respiratory disease|respiratory]] and [[Cardiovascular disease|cardiovascular disorders]], [[Cancer|malignancies]] and [[Autoimmune disease|autoimmune disorders]].
===Impeding factors=== Among other factors that may impede the healing of a wound are:<ref>{{cite journal |last=Anderson |first=K|last2=Hamm |first2=R |date=December 2012 |title=Factors That Impair Wound Healing |url= https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4495737|journal= Advances in Wound Care |volume=4|issue=4 |pmc= 4495737|doi= 10.1016/j.jccw.2014.03.001}}</ref><ref name="Factors">{{cite journal |last=Guo |first=S|last2=Dipietro |first2=LA |date=March 2010 |title= Factors affecting wound healing |journal= Journal of Dental Research |volume=89|issue=3 |pmid= 20139336|doi= 10.1177/0022034509359125|pmc=2903966}}</ref> * patient’s age<ref>{{cite journal |last=Gosain |first=A|last2=Dipietro |first2=L |date=March 2004|title= Aging and wound healing |journal= World Journal of Surgery |volume=28|issue=3|pmid= 14961191| doi= 10.1007/s00268-003-7397-6}}</ref> * [[obesity]]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Wilson |first=JA|last2=Clark |first2=JJ |date=April–June 2003|title= Obesity: impediment to wound healing |journal=Critical Care Nursing Quarterly |volume=26|issue=2|pmid=12744592}}</ref> * presence of [[infection]]<ref name="Factors" /> * poor [[nutrition]] or hydration<ref name="Nutr1">{{cite journal |last=Arnold |first=M|last2=Barbul|first2=A |date=June 2006|title= Nutrition and wound healing |url= http://journals.lww.com/plasreconsurg/Abstract/2006/06001/Nutrition_and_Wound_Healing.7.aspx |journal= Plastic & Reconstructive Surgery |volume=117|issue=7S| doi= 10.1097/01.prs.0000225432.17501.6c }}</ref><ref name="Nutr2">{{cite journal |last=Russell |first=L |date=March 2001 |title= The importance of patients' nutritional status in wound healing |journal=British Journal of Nursing |volume=10 |issue=6S|pmid= 12070399| doi= 10.12968/bjon.2001.10.Sup1.5336}}</ref> * [[Prescription drug|prescribed medication]]<ref>{{cite journal |date=April 2013 |title= Drugs that delay wound healing |journal=Prescrire International |volume=22 |issue=137|pmid= 23662318}}</ref> * [[substance abuse]] and [[smoking]]<ref>{{cite journal |last= Silverstein |first=P |date=July 1992 |title= Smoking and wound healing |journal=American Journal of Medicine |volume=93 |issue=1A|pmid= 1323208}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Finnie |first=A|last2= Nicolson |first2=P |date=March 2002|title= Injecting drug use: implications for skin and wound management|journal= British Journal of Nursing|volume=11|issue=6S| pmid=11979188| doi= 10.12968/bjon.2002.11.Sup1.12246}}</ref> * general effect of the wound on a patient’s lifestyle (pain, wound odor, excessive drainage)<ref>{{cite journal |last=Price |first=P|last2= Krasner |first2=DL |date=August 2014|title= Health-related quality of life & chronic wounds |url= http://www.todayswoundclinic.com/articles/health-related-quality-life-chronic-wounds |journal= Today’s Wound Clinic|volume=8|issue=6}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Faria|first=E|last2=Blanes|first2=L|last3=Hochman|first3=B|last4=Filho|first4=MM|last5=Ferreira|first5=L |date=January 2011 |title= Health-related quality of life, self-esteem, and functional status of patients with leg ulcers|url= http://www.woundsresearch.com/article/health-related-quality-life-self-esteem-and-functional-status-patients-leg-ulcers|journal= Wounds: a compendium of clinical research and practice|volume=23 |issue=1}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Herber|first=OR|last2=Schnepp|first2=W|last3=Rieger|first3=MA |date=July 2007 |title= A systematic review on the impact of leg ulceration on patients' quality of life|journal= Health and Quality of Life Outcomes |volume=5 |pmc= 1947954 |doi= 10.1186/1477-7525-5-44 }}</ref>
===Wound=== ====Wound cause==== If the wound is [[Chronic wound|chronic]], is it the result of: an underlying illness (diabetic, venous and arterial ulcers), poor handling of the patient ([[Pressure ulcer|pressure injuries]], [[Deep Tissue Injury|deep tissue injuries]], wounds with cavities and undermining), poor previous treatment choices that slowed down the healing (untreated infection, inappropriate wound care product choice, lack of necessary procedures).<ref>{{cite journal |last= Frykberg |first=RG|last2= Banks |first2=J |date=September 2015|title= Challenges in the treatment of chronic wounds |journal= Advances in Wound Care|volume=4|issue=9| pmc= 4528992| doi=10.1089/wound.2015.0635}}</ref> If the wound is acute, is it the result of: [[Injury|traumatic injury]], [[burn]], or [[surgery]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Nicks|first=BA|last2=Ayello|first2=EA|last3=Woo|first3=K|last4= Nitzki-George |first4=D|last5= Sibbald |first5=RG |date=December 2010 |title= Acute wound management: revisiting the approach to assessment, irrigation, and closure considerations|journal= International Journal of Emergency Medicine|volume=3 |issue=4|pmc= 3047833|doi=10.1007/s12245-010-0217-5}}</ref>
====Wound duration==== For chronic wounds: time the current wound has been present, is it a recurring wound, how many times it has recurred in the past, how long it took to heal each time. For acute wounds: when the wound was first acquired before the clinician visit.
====Wound state==== Wound bed, wound edge and periwound skin should be examined before the initial treatment plan is devised. It should also be re-assessed at each visit or each dressing change.
For wound bed, the following parameters are assessed: * Tissue type; presence and percentage of non-viable tissue covering the wound bed * Level of [[exudate]] * Presence of infection
Wound edge must be examined to detect:<ref>{{cite journal |last=Benbow |first=M |date=March 2016 |title= Best practice in wound assessment |journal=Nursing Standard |volume=30 |issue=27|pmid=26932649 |doi= 10.7748/ns.30.27.40.s45}}</ref> * Maceration * Desiccation * Undermining * Elevation above surrounding tissue (raised edge) * Epibole (rolled edge)
For periwound skin, the following conditions should be diagnosed or ruled out:<ref name="Challenges">{{cite journal |last= Hollinworth |first=H|date=October 2009 |title= Challenges in protecting peri-wound skin|journal=Nursing Standard |volume=24 |issue=7|pmid=19927560|doi= 10.7748/ns2009.10.24.7.53.c7330 }}</ref><ref name="Disorders">{{cite journal |last=Woo |first=KY |last2=Ayello |first2=EA |last3=Sibbald |first3=G.|date= 2009 |title= The skin and periwound skin disorders and management |url=http://www.woundhealingsa.co.za/index.php/WHSA/article/view/58/79 |journal= Wound Healing Southern Africa |volume=2 |issue=2 }}</ref> * Maceration * Dry, scaly skin * Desiccation * Excoriation and skin stripping * Hypergranulation and hyperkeratosis * [[Dermatitis|Eczema]] * Callus build-up and epibole * Infection and inflammation
